description:
Overall had a fantastic omakase experience at Tsubasa Sushi. 

Picked the 12 pieces omakase $80/ person. The whole dinner took about 2.5 hours long. 

Food:
My favorite nigiri were the blue shrimp, scallop, snapper with uni on top, snow crab, chu toro, uni, wagyu. 

Their fish selection is fairly on the leaner side and the flavor is on the refreshing side for at least the first 8 nigiri. The last few pieces were the more heavy/ buttery fish including toro, uni and wagyu (for free). 

One thing I liked about the sushi is that the rice portion is very small.

Paired this meal with Dassai. It's a very refreshing and slightly sweet sake. $35/180ml bottle 

Ambience and service: 
I sat at the bar and our sushi chef created a very fun experience for us. He kept giving me extra pieces of toro on the side to be funny and also added an extra nigiri with no charge. 

They can also switch out any fish that you don't like and substitute it with something else.
author: Teresa Z.

description:
I ain't gonna lie, this is the best sushi I've had in my life. You can read my reviews, and yes I've said this multiple times. But tsubasa is special. It's in a classy enclave of SF, but without the classic SF uppityness. 

Great cuts of fish, and no wonder they're Michelin rated. 

Super amazing stuff. We go once every 3 weeks from Reno and love it all. 

So now Tsubasa has the crown in our book, and beats out LA, SD, and Scottsdale.
author: Phil D.

description:
I luv nigiris so much!
Thanks to the yelp that lead us to this fantastic sushi restaurant in Hayes Valley District. 

Omakase (12 pieces) was stunning and featured different kinds of fresh fish that all melted in your mouth.

The chefs were very experienced and knew how to use different kinds of sauce to elevate the freshness of the fish.  Each one has a unique taste, and the rice that bedded the fish was in good texture.

Definitely recommend to all the sushi lovers.
author: Regina W.

description:
We made reservations through yelp a week before however the day of, I had to add a couple more to our party. So I called Tsubasa Sushi and they were very accommodating and changed the reservations to 5. When we arrived out table was waiting for us and seated right away. The menu has a good variety of items including fresh fish. Our server was efficient in taking orders from every one and bringing out our beers and sake. We ordered the following:

Omakase Nigiri: 12 pcs. Good variety smaller cuts of fish.
Omakase sashimi: 15 pcs 5 different fish very good
Toro: really fatty and decadent topped with gold flakes
Uni with salmon roe: best dish of the night Uni is always better with just a little bit of rice (comes with a small portions of rice) the salmon roe was so fresh and texture tight. 
Scallops nigiri: good
Ankimo: small portions
Scallops roll: excellent the scallops were very fresh yesterday. 
Salmon skin salad: nicely charred salmon skin on a bed of greens
Chawan Mushi: very small cup of steamed egg custard comes with snow crab.
Snow crab with seaweed and cucumbers OTH

Veggies:
Goma Asparagus
Cucumbers 
Marinated eggplant OTH
Marinated tomatoes OTH

Desserts
Yusu sorbet
Milk Tea ice cream

Nice space, good service, a bit pricey in relation to portion size. Very good variety of fish and kitchen items. Parking garage 1 block away $18.
author: George F.

description:
One of my favorite omakase experiences in SF without a doubt. The space is cozy and intimate; call ahead to make reservations, especially if you're coveting a seat at the bar (which you def should if you're doing omakase). 

For omakase, there are three tiers, with the highest one being 12 pcs, which we both opted for. Tsubasa also offers some of the most reasonably priced deals I've seen for the level of quality and cuts served. Every single piece was fresh and loved the variety of more unique types of fish. Fan of the fish to rice ratio here. What we had listed below, and favorites marked with *:

+Appetizer
+Hirame*
+Japanese seabass
+Arctic char from Canada*
+Baby yellowtail
+Hokkaido scallop
+Baby amberjack
+Bluenose butterfish
+Mackerel chub*
+Chutoro
+Japanese barracuda with uni
+Japanese snow crab with miso*
+Wagyu

Bonus points for the eggplant "palette cleanser" halfway through the meal as well as the delicious and aesthetically pleasing tomato balls presented at the end for a simple dessert. 

Sushi chef here was on the less talkative side, though he did check in a few times to see how we were liking the cuts. Note that the omakase does take an extremely long time so plan accordingly. Ours lasted two and a half hours, which was a little too much for me. Even if I'm doing omakase, unless it's something truly special and spectacular, I want to be in-and-out in two hours or less.
author: Kell S.

description:
We came here to fulfill our craving for sushi for dinner during our last trip to SF.

Fortunately, I made reservations on Yelp and was seated right away by the hostess. I'd recommend making reservations because this place seemed popular.

We were seated by the window and service was great. We were going to go with the omakase but decided to just order a la carte from the menu.

We ordered the following:
-Chawanmushi (steamed egg custard): We ordered one with uni (sea urchin) and another one with unagi (freshwater eel). The egg custard was flavorful and soft. The uni was fresh and added a creamy texture and richness to the egg custard. The unagi was nicely grilled and added a great flavor as well.
-Oshizushi (pressed sushi with chopped blue fin tuna with scallions and sesame seeds): This was served as 7 pieces of sushi with freshly chopped wasabi and some chopped daikon. The flavors were amazing and this was definitely one of our favorites of the night. I'd highly recommend it!

Nigiri
-Muki Hotate (scallop)
-Zuawai Kani (snow crab)
-Kagoshima Wagyu (beef)
-Japanese Uni (sea urchin)
-Mirugai (longneck clam)
All the pieces of nigiri were really tasty! They served big pieces of seafood over a small bite of rice, which reminded me of the portions we had in Japan. 

Dessert
Black Sesame Panna Cotta: The panna cotta was smooth. It was served with anko (red bean paste) and some matcha powder. I loved the taste and flavor of the black sesame seed. Great way to end the meal!

Overall, I'd come back for some delicious sushi without having to pay more than $100 per person.
author: Lily Y.

description:
The master chef, Rich I believe, was phenom!
Sat at a table w my family last night at 5:30pm 
and ordered the WHOLE menu haha as usual how Persians do.

ORDERED: 
- POUNDS of fresh wasabi- heaven  
- Salmon Skin Salad- Wonderful 
- 3 Seaweed Salads- Great yet too much sauce
- Salmon Avo cut rolls- My sis approved 
- Spicy Tuna cut rolls- Also fam approved 
- Iwashi (Sardine) Sashimi
- Lightly seared Barracuda w a dab of Jap Uni on top Sashimi- A MUST!!!!!
- Arctic Char- Yum
- Ocean Trout- Yum 
- Medai (Butterfish) Kama- yum but needed to be cooked longer 
- King Salmon Sashimi
- Albacore Tataki 
- Hot Sake for my Uncle 

Pro: WONDERFUL Server- Steven!! 
         And all Chefs 
         Tasty AF food

Con: Food prep was a bit long
author: Cat Zaimi, M A.

description:
I really want to like Tsubasa, but it was a bit of a let down after reading all the glowing Yelp reviews. I was excited to try the 12 piece Omakase, but for $80 I don't think the flavors warranted the price tag. 

Wagyu, Scallop, and Toro were my favorite. Note that the wagyu was ordered separately and didn't come with the 12 piece Omakase. It was super high quality meat that melted in your mouth. 

Least favorite were all the pieces of sushi with shiso leaves. They was a bitter flavor to the leaves that completely overpowered the fish. Furthermore, the leaves added a dryness to the bite of the sushi that made it unappealing. I don't think I would of minded it that much, but it wasn't just 1 piece of sushi that had shiso but multiple pieces maybe 3. I also don't think the quality of the fish was at high as other Omakase places I've been to, especially the halibut which I love, but unfortunately it tasted a bit salty. 

I've also been to Omakase places, where each bite was very thoughtful and seemed to build flavors on top of the next bite. Unfortunately Tsubasa didn't deliver the same experience.
author: Steve C.

description:
We came here for one of our first omakase experiences. Made reservations for a weekend night. The restaurant was packed. Hot spot for date night. Not super fancy, so can dress nice, but still casual. 

It wasn't my favorite omakase experiences tbh. Some of the fish selections were a bit too fishy. Like the mackerel and the sardine. Maybe it was just the selection of fish I wasn't a fan of. 

And then one of my nigiri pieces had a slight bone in it. Which then made me wary. I don't think that should be happening for the price you pay at such a high end restaurant. 

Any way I was hoping it was better, but not as impressed.
author: Lara D.

description:
(4.5 stars) Wonderfully authentic and delicious meal. Stopped in for dinner on a brisk summer night after seeing its Bib Gourmand status and it did not disappoint. Plus id you're more of a roll than sashimi person like I am, it's really not too pricey at all. 

The basic rolls--like spicy tuna which was freaken delicious, like seriously adding soy sauce like I typically need to with most sushi spots would've actually detracted from it-- are super reasonable. The more extravagant rolls--like the holy crab roll aren't cheap but definitely worth trying. I actually preferred the simpler roll, the holy crab felt like a bit too much was going on and the crab kinda drowned out the eel, plus the sauce was more sweet than spicy while I was hoping for the opposite. That said though, still worth trying and absolutely worth stopping in. The miso soup alone will hit the spot.
author: Jason S.

description:
Fish is not fresh, hamachi is overcooked!
Toro is not fresh. I am not sure why is different from other post on the Yelp
author: Phoebe W.

description: Excellent sushi and service! Nothing particularly special, follows the usual pattern, but the dishes were all delicious and the service was fantastic, and the price was reasonable. I'd definitely go back. The sushi scene here is so crowded and so competitive, it's hard to stand out!
author: Eater S.

description: Overall nice. Fish is good quality, service is friendly. We had a few rolls, a few pieces of nigiri, and some appetizers. The nigiri were all missing something in their seasoning (not up to omakase style preparation, but better than average). Standouts were the chawanmushi with uni and the torotaku. The futomaki was tasty but a bit too loosely wrapped. The juicy scallop roll was a bit too monotonous in texture (could have used a crunch). I'll visit them again for sure.
author: Marie L.

description:
I'm shocked we never tried Tsubasa before (to be honest, I had doubts about sushi in Hayes Valley) but we decided to try a new sushi spot on a whim. So thankful we checked this place out! Made last minute reservations relatively easily via phone for 930pm on Saturday night, and we were seated at the bar. 

Definitely go for the 12 piece omakase. Compared to other omakase options in the city, it's relatively affordable ($80) plus you get a lot of pieces (they give you a few extra surprises on top of the 12 pieces!) I really enjoyed the fish - incredibly fresh and high quality. The pieces from Japan were amazing and we had multiple varieties of toro/chu toro and uni in multiple preparations. Standouts included the cherry blossom salmon (wrapped in a cherry blossom leaf from Japan), toro (topped with gold flecks), Chu toro (came with a little extra), salmon belly topped with uni, and uni with Ikura. Everything was so tasty and really worth it! 

The sushi chefs were super friendly, and we really enjoyed sitting at the bar. Would definitely come back again!
author: Sally C.

description:
Hands down the best Omakase authentic experience I have had. I am always on a mission to find new spots and this is so affordable and palette teasing.

There were 3 chefs at the bar, and Peter was our main chef. He explained every fish: what it was and where it's from. 

My favorites? Octopus, Scallop, Salmon. 

The experience was a cherry on top for my boyfriend's birthday and honestly for the price tag, it's worth the extra $$$.

There are little appetizers dishes in between some of the courses which by the end of the dinner probably why I am soooooooo full. I almost could not finish and eat any dessert. 


Thank you Tsubasa!!!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I loveeee this place, the service and the food!

My boyfriend and I came here for our anniversary dinner, and we ordered two 12 piece omakases and one sashimi omakase as well. The fish was AMAZING! The toro - OMG, melted in my mouth. The uni was so dang good too. I really enjoyed every piece that we had. 

Our server, Kristy, was really kind and really walked us through each plating. She was such a sweetheart and noticed every small detail that was going on. I didn't really like the wasabi in my omakase - she noticed and had it taken out from the rest of my plating. (i tried really hard to keep it OG but i couldnt lmao) The dessert was this locally made icecream (it was so good too! but apparently this changes from time to time~)

She also gave us a tip of sitting at the bar - that way we get our pieces one at a time instead of 4 at a time (when you're at a table).

Overall I loved the 12 piece omakase the most and I'm definitely going to come back!
author: Melanie T.

description: Had the nigiri omakase and it was pretty good. You can tell the freshness of the fish and the quality of the fish. I liked their pickled eggplant and cherry tomatoes if that's what they're called. Lol. Went here for drop-in since there were no more reservations available through Open Table and we were actually seated right away. Good place!
author: Mark S.

description:
Amazing as always. Tried a couple of new items on the menu. The bluefin tataki and the carter roll were delicious. Also got to try some new nigiris they might add to the menu! 

Chef Peter never disappoints :)
author: Laura D.

description:
This review is long overdue, but it's given me the opportunity to say what most people can't - I've come back to eat here 3 separate times, and it deserves 5 stars every.single.meal. 

Chef Chris & Peter are not only skilled behind the knife, but they explain each dish to you and WHY you are receiving them in a certain order. They take care to understand what your food preferences are, and if you are inclined to give them creative control - do it. Japanese food in the traditional way it would be served - how could we say no? 

The previous time my friend and I dined there, we had just embarked on a keto journey (or at least I had), and she soon followed suit as Chef Chris proceeded to make us an entirely KETO OMAKASE dinner!!!! I couldn't believe my eyes. It left me so satisfied, and I didn't miss the sushi rice one bit. To be honest, I was almost ready to throw in the towel and forgo my keto commitment that day, but I didn't have to. The chefs delivered. That in and of itself is an example of how they will go above and beyond to make sure your time at Tsubasa is something that you will never forget. 

Do NOT leave there without asking trying their tiered tuna nigiri plate, in order from lean to fatty meat. Each piece is delightful, and has you appreciate each part of the fish.

They recently added Black Sesame Panna Cotta on their menu, and it's the best dessert I've had all year. My friend preferred the Green Tea, but I recommend ordering both and having your fill. You won't regret it. 

Thanks guys. I'm officially addicted, and unfortunately disappointed in most other sushi places across the city. 

PS: and if you find out you have a surprise allergic reaction to shrimp after having eaten it for 28 years of your life, don't worry. They have Zyrtec on hand, so you can proceed with your meal. (hahahah we're not quitters)

10/10. Can't wait to see you all again!!
author: Tiba G.

description:
We've all had bad tastes in our mouths.

It may stem from losing money on the tables.  It may stem from failing a test, although you knew the right answers all along. It could be caused from buying something at full price, and watch it go on sale the next day.  Or it could be from being stood up for a meeting, or worse yet, for a date.

I know at Tsubasa, bad taste will not be from the food you eat.  Bad taste won't linger even if you eat Iwashi, the rare seasonal sardine which has the strongest flavor on the menu.  If you're lucky, you'll get the Hokkaido uni with salmon roe on sisho leaf which will make you forget all of your bad tastes.

Tsubasa, I can't blame any bad taste on you...it must come from something else.
author: Ron L.

description:
Delicious, relatively affordable spot for omakase in Hayes Valley. I stopped by Tsubasa after a Saturday evening Warriors game at Oracle Arena, and they were gracious enough to seat me with no issue even though we were running a little late. 

Loved everything we had but the standouts for me were definitely the chu-toro (everything tastes a little better when topped with gold :) and the uni with ikura.

Would love to come back and sit at the bar next time!
author: Kelly R.

description:
I came across Tsubasa Sushi when I wanted to do Omakase in San Francisco. 

ATMOSPHERE:
The place is a very modern, no frills kind of sushi place. No need to dress up compared to other Omakase places. 

SERVICE:
The service was impeccable here. We had a 8 PM reservation at the sushi bar and once we arrived we were seated right away at the side of the sushi bar which was the best seat of the entire place! Thanks Tsubasa! 

FOOD:
The 12 piece Omakase here was amazing! Each piece was perfectly made and the chefs described each piece as it was sit before us. They also gave us a few complimentary dishes here and there. We also ordered the steamed monkfish as an appetizer and we enjoyed that a lot. I've never had monkfish before and the texture of it reminded me a lot of ham which was quite surprising. 

The 12 piece Omakase lasted about an hour and a half so if you plan on getting that make sure you plan well!

The chef that served us majority of our dishes also gave us a few extra pieces of toro which was amazing and so nice of him to do. 

Thank you so much Tsubasa! I'll definitely recommend this place to any of my friends visiting San Francisco!
author: Belle L.

description:
[[ October 2017 Omakase - $95 total after tax/tip ]]

Cheap.
High quality ingredients.
Friendly chefs serving us.

I always recommend sitting at the bar and so you could interact with the chef or at least see how he works. Ask for bar seating when you make your reservation.

The chefs described every piece they handed over and everything was super beautifully presented + amazingly fresh. 

We received 12-ish pieces and I say ish because the chef gave us a little extra here and there, like he noticed we really enjoyed the scallop so he gave a little more or when he gave us toro, he also handed over a second little piece. My faves: scallop, chu toro, o toro, uni. Was also pleasantly surprised by the dessert which was a tomato? 

Will definitely be back.
author: Elvi T.

description:
The sushi is definitely top-grade and it's not cheap. I love Hayes Valley, and I'm surprised that it took me so long to try it. I was confused by the "extra note" when trying to make a Yelp reservation that they have seating times around 5:30pm and 8:30pm. But the part I missed was "walk-ins welcome anytime". Should have known. On Sunday nights, Hayes Valley is pretty darn busy and we were able to get seated at Tsubasa fairly easily. 

We got the asparagus appetizer, 10-piece omakase, Juicy Scallop roll and Toro nigiri. The fish was amazing. You can tell how good a place is by their Maguro. It was melt in your mouth. I ordered the Toro towards the end of dinner because I had to try it. Splendid. 

The staff is attentive and nice. So overall, I plan on coming back here.
author: Young Y.

description:
Fresh sushi, great Omakase selection for the price $$! What a steal!  We sat at the sushi bar for our Omakase birthday dinner.  The head chef even threw in extra pieces because it was a bday celebration which was awesome and very much appreciated.

My only negative comment would be that during the entire duration of our meal, we didn't see any of the sushi chefs wash their hands.  
Yikes. Because of that one reason, I can't recommend this place to my friends.  If we are ever in the area, we will definitely come back and give it another go, but it was a bit unsettling for my stomach to see them handle EVERYTHING and not touch the handsink once.
author: Kay H.

description:
First time getting omakase! I believe they went up in price just a tad for the 12 course nigiri. 

The chef started out with a yummy raw oyster. It was very refreshing. Every piece of nigiri was raw and unique to the way the chef prepared. They were all fresh and tasted superb! I was impatient with the process and I ordered a roll of sushi and it was too much (just a side note). Our chef wasn't all that interactive so our experience was lacking. He just tells the name of the fish and where they came from. 

It was a good experience but I'd want a better interactions.
author: Vinh D.

description:
The fish here is remarkably fresh and the selection is far more diverse than what you usually see from a typical sushi restaurant. I think they do a good job importing some of the seasonal fish and keeping their menus up to date with the latest and greatest. Among the nigiri highlights were the tennen buri (wild yellowtail), kinmedai (goldeneye snapper) and the Sakura masu (cherry blossom trout). I'd ask for the shiso leaves to be removed from our dishes the next time I come, as the scent is particularly strong and pungent if you are not used to it. The Oshizushi also stood out from the specialty maki section for delivering a unique, fresh, and delicious taste; the juicy scallop rolls were some of the freshest scallops I've tasted in SF. 

Service was a tad slow, we would receive our orders  with a bit of a delay, but otherwise a good experience
author: David Y.

description:
Where in the bay area can you get a 12 course Omakase for 68.00?  Not that many places I'll  tell you!   We made reservations to come here for dinner after our broadway show.  The place is pretty small, so i recommend you plan ahead.  It's located right in Hayes Valley so parking can be a little hard.   The server seated us pretty quick and did a quick wrap up of the menu.  We both decided on the 12 course meal,and boy i did not regret it!   They place our sushi on one plate and piece by piece they brought it out one at time after we both finished.   I love the service here and i can't get enough of the uni because actually melts in your mouth.   Here are a few other things we ordered

Cherry blossom salmon- so good
Scallop Hokkaido - so good
Black snapper
Flounder- my least fav
toro belly tuna- So good, also melts in your mouth
Barracuda topped with uni- very smooth
Artic something- 
Kimbichi hamata
butterfish
Uni-The most amazing uni ever!
gold line snapper
eggplant
totoro
dessert- tomato

if parking here wasn't so hard, i would come back more often.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Our experience was AMAZING. Staff was courteous and attentive. Food was even better. 

Went with wife and 2 kids. Ordered the Nigiri Omakase (12 pcs), Sashimi Omakase (15 pcs), Juicy Scallop Roll and the Rainbow Roll as fillers. Fish was fresh, the nigiri courses made sense. Palate cleansers were yummy, too. The green tea ice cream with rice cracker was a winner. Have you had a candied tomato? Well, time to try it here!

HIGHLY recommended and would definitely revisit.
author: Victor W.

description: Tsubasa is surprisingly delicious. I was surprised I was able to snag reservations on a Friday, same day reservation, by phone. We arrived early but we were seated as soon as a table became free. We were seated in a spacious table and it was very comfortable. What we order was an bottle of Dragons might delicious sake they gave us complimentary crab sunomono, after that we order the Special Sashimi very good very fresh the assortment of fish which were beautifully plated could not recall all of the fishes since they were so many. We also order some seared salmon belly nigiri, unagi nigiri, The Holy Crab roll, and This chu toro square roll, and we finished it all with Uni dish served with rice and salmon roe. All in all solid 4 stars will be returning back to this delicious sushi spot.
author: Timothy C.

description:
I was in the area for smitten ice cream and was craving for sushi so I yelped this restaurant as it has good ratings. This place was so hard to make reservations and a fellow yelper was right, they never pick up the phone. I decided to walk in here around 5 pm and make the reservation for 5:30 pm. The second I walked in, I was kind of regretting because there was no AC in the restaurant... it doesn't really matter but on a 103 degree day in SF- everything matters. Since I already came here, I do want to give this place a try. I went ahead and made the reservation for 5:30 and was seated right when they open. The place was nearly half empty even though it reached 6:30. I think they limited the online reservations because they want to be available to walk-ins also. 

For appetizer, we opted in to order their agedashi tofu and tofu salad as the server told us that it was their first day of serving it 9/1/17! The agedashi tofu $8 was just average/OK nothing special about it but the tofu salad $10 was pretty refreshing. My party and I ordered their omakase of 12 pcs nigiri $75/person. To begin the omakase, we got the crab meat over cucumber salad then the 12 pcs of nigiri with a fried eggplant to snack. We ended the meal with a soup we ordered as to what they called the special soup: red snapper collar soup $7/each bowl. The pricing isn't steep for its quality of fish but think of this omakase in a casual style way, you won't have to dress up for any dress code. Over all, the quality of the fish is fresh but the nigiri rice did not taste very authentic.
author: Sammi L.

description: Chill ambience, service top notch. Tried omakase twice, great experience with reasonable cost. Highly recommended if you in the neighborhood.
author: Yiran P.

description:
Fab sushi place - it has pressed sushi, which I know is not the same as the ones you get in New York, Vancouver, or Japan but for San Francisco, this is pretty unusual and definitely worth getting. Before nigiri, which was fast food sushi developed during the industrialization phase of Japan, pressed sushi was it - it's flavorful, generally consists of some sort of seasoning in the rice, and it's condensed and pressed so that the flavor is packed with the fish on top. A typical pressed sushi is mackerel sushi, but this evening on their dinner special they also had a toro pressed sushi.

Their omakase sashimi is very fresh and incredibly well priced for the neighborhood. The presentation was great. The daily special marinated fish was pretty to eat. 

I quite liked the house made tamago, slightly different than the ones you get from the ones that were from pre-made tamago. 

What I loved about this place is presentation. Everything on the dish is pretty to look at. And the quality of the fish is better than most. 

I think about the many sushi places I've been, most of them are just mediocre. The rice to fish ratio is not always good. The quality of fish and the variety of it also not great. This place has your everyday affair sushi and it has also a great selection of daily specials which makes you feel so very special.

Hayes Valley's food scene is very competitive, and I've been eating around here sine the late 90s to see some changes. I understand this place has been around for an year and half. I rarely eat at the same place twice, but this place will see quite a bit of me, as long as I can stay put for a while (which fingers crossed will be the case in October!)
author: Victoria E.

description:
12 piece Omakase for $68?! SUCHA STEAL!

Arrived early for our party of 4, 8:00pm reservation and we were seated instantly upon arrival. It was a full house with people waiting outside the restaurant. That's a good sign! Sat at the sushi bar and was greeted by the friendly sushi chefs Peter and John. We all opted for the 12 piece omakase and Chef Peter made sure to get all our allergies, likes, and dislikes before serving. 

Omakase Options includes: 
4pc for $20..... 8pc for $44...... 12pc for $68

STARTERS:
- Crab over cucumber
- Octopus over cucumber (for me cause i'm allergic to crab)
- Octopus with ponzo, tobiko, and lemon

OMAKASE:
- (forgot) something with Plum
- Madai Konbujime (red snapper)
- Tako Ashi (raw japanese Octopus)
- Kanpachi (amberjack)
- Muki Hotate (fresh scallop)
- Hirame (flounder) yumm, love the shiso leaf underneath! thanks Chef Peter
- Chu-Toro (bluefin tuna) 
- Ika (squid)
- Another kind of Hotate?
- Toro Kama (so fatty, melted in your mouth and topped with these three gold flaked balls)
- Uni and Ikura  (best for last. Uni was sweet and ikura was a burst of flavors)

OTHER DISHES:
- Nasu Agedashi (Fried eggplant in bonito broth)
- Fried squid with matcha powder and salt? 
- This fried fish
- Unagi Tempura from Chef John!! so delicious 

Honestly, I've been on a prowl for an affordable AND great quality sushi joint for a while and this place is IT! Lots of other good sushi restaurants in SF offers omakase's for $100+ and for less items, Tsubasa is one place that offers 12 pieces for a whopping $68!! woo hoo! From the fresh and delicious nigiri's to the great attentive service and friendly funny chefs, Tsubasa has really exceeded my expectations in terms of service and food and for such an affordable price. Both chefs are really knowledgeable and talented and they really strive to give customers a memorable dinging experience. Throughout our meal, we were well taken care of. The chefs explained every nigiri they gave us and we even had a few in-between complimentary dishes to help cleanse our palette (ex: eggplant in sweet broth) Everything was simply amazing! We even had the chance to "kanpai" with both chefs!
author: Anissa D.

description:
So the red sign outside makes Tsubasa look kind of tacky and cheap but the interior is modern and cleanly decorated, so don't be fooled like I was!

Get. The. Omakase! They change that menu daily and when I went they had 12 pieces for $80 including one of their most expensive seasonal pieces of fish and a healthy portion of uni, it's a steal. The fish to rice ratio was great, which is to me a big portion of fish and a much smaller portion of seasoned rice. All of the nigiri pieces I had were interesting and tasty and the staff always asked how you liked the fish after so they could adjust the amount of wasabi or anything if you wanted, so nice! 

Also they know the way to my heart, lots of mini courses/palette cleansers in between aka "free stuff" so that always makes me happier. 

Definitely give this place a try!
author: Crystal C.

description:
The Failure of Success
What a disappointment after my previous glowing reviews!  Again, I made reservation here prior to the Opera, expecting the good food and service wife and I came to expect.  However, there was something very different this time. We arrived here at about ten minutes before 5:30 PM, their opening time, and there was actually a line of about ten people waiting for it to open.  When it opened and we were seated, the restaurant was almost full, and people kept coming in.  Much busier than ever before.  We ordered the monk fish with ponzu sauce as appetizer, and as usual, wife ordered the deluxe sashimi ($80) and I ordered the Omakase Sushi 12 pieces ($80) that are served in four separate servings.   The Sashimi and my first 4 pieces of sushi came promptly, but then it took  more than 40 minutes for my second plate of sushi to arrive, which left very little time before the Opera.  I complained and asked all the remaining dishes be served immediately - it took at least another 15 minutes for the two additional dishes to arrive, by which time I lost much appetite.  Wife did enjoy her sashimi, but I felt my sushi was at best mediocre, unlike the absolutely delicious fresh sushi I used to enjoy here.  I doubt we will come here again at least for a long time (by which time I hope they will have mended their ways!)
author: Hoyle L.

description: I was pleasantly surprised with our meal at Tsubasa sushi, definitely a solid pick if you are looking to stay in SF and stay within a reasonable budget. Most sushi is either on the cheaper end, or very expensive, and Tsubasa was somewhere in the middle. All three of us ate for about 40 bucks each, but we did not drink. The roles were standard size, and the atmosphere was perfect for a date, and right in the middle of Hayes Valley. I will probably be back again, and was happy with the experience I had.
author: Ross S.

description: Interesting place offering a nice omakase set.  Friendly chefs and some interesting combinations and flavors which is super great.  That said, the place could be described as homey or rustic...I would just say cluttered.  It does kinda offset the vibe here which is a shame.  Course if the trade off is cluttered and affordable vs sleek and expensive; we can just keep it cluttered. Either way, I'll be back.
author: David S.

description: Tbh, underwhelming. For $$$ non-fusion Japanese cuisine, check out Saru Sushi, which offers more attention to detail and significantly better taste. Try Kusakabe if you're willing to drop $$$$. You're going to spend a good amount on mediocre food at Tsubasa unless you want to leave hungry.
author: Paulina F.

description:
They charge $25 for a bottle of sparkling sake that costs $9 in Japantown.

Not much complaint other than that.
author: Tao Q.

description: Quite disappointing experience for the price ($80 for 12 piece omakase) you'd expect professional service. Omakase was good  but mannnn was the wait for each piece unevenly spaced out and the longest wait between pieces was almost 15 minutes.  We were seated at the corner of the bar and we couldn't even see what the chef was doing because he was making our sushi with his back to us in the corner where the sink was - is that even sanitary? The chef who was in front of us wasn't the one serving us, super awkward. The first 6 pieces took an hour to come out and then the last 6 was half an hour. Like I said, weird time spaces. Good part was we got a few free dishes! But would I go back? Nahhhhh
author: Siri E.

description:
I love this place!  The service is spot on... they're warm and friendly and extremely helpful with their not so normal selection of sushi fish.  They make me happy (more advanced sushi eater) and others too (rolls with ungagi and crab and things). I can't wait to go back to try  more.  


And another time for a happy review.  My favorite restaurant in the city.   Worth any wait.  It's better than kusakabe and robin. Hands down.
author: Shannon S.

description:
Very good sushi at a decent price, harder to find in SF than you would think!

First of all, you must try the savory mochi appetizer. It is topped with bonito flakes and in a delicious umami broth. Just warm enough and melts in your mouth! Perfect amuse bouche.

The head sushi chef is definitely a character! He really made the experience of dining here for us! He's so funny and surprised us with so many delicious dishes. The toro nigiri was topped in gold flakes and perfect brushed with soy, with just the right touch of wasabi! The uni presentation was like nothing I'd seen before, so cute, and so tasty (small portion though).

Leave Domo and Nara behind, this is where you can get the best sushi in the neighborhood.

TIP: They seem disappointed when people order hot sake lol... just order cold and share with the chefs!
author: Kimia M.

description:
The omakase was amazing. 12 different nigiri's each had its own unique flavor that didn't require dipping in soy sauce. The waitress was very knowledgeable about each of the nigiri and explained to us what each one was. Saving the best for last, the uni was to die for. 

Came here on a Friday around 6pm. We did have reservations because it could get very crowded a little later in the night and especially on weekends. To my surprise it wasn't that busy when we arrived. It was a perfect time to come (although maybe we just got lucky) because it started to get crowded when we were finishing. 

Very reasonable pricing for a 12 piece omakase and definitely high quality fish!!!
author: Justin Y.

description:
You won't leave disappointed. I was definitely skeptical prior to making reservations because it was either here or Akiko (haven't been to either). Settled with Tsubasa because of the affordability. 

Great meal; quality fish and superb service. I encountered a drunk man (seated at the bar) and he ALMOST ruined my meal. Thankfully, the head chef noticed and apologized on his behalf. The chef obviously didn't have to go out of his way but I appreciated it. Gave us a discount on our bill.

Order the omakase. I usually don't because I'd probably enjoy 50% of the chefs choice... but I took a chance and was glad I did. I ended up ordering several nigiri pieces too but was informed that some were already included in the omakase. They opted for other cuts of fish and I couldn't have been happier.

I kept my expectations very low, but after dining in,  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone that's in the city looking for quality and affordable sushi.

Tsubasa takes care of you and your palate. Trust them.
author: Katie L.

description:
Rumor has it the sushi comes from Tsukiji Market. We didn't have time for the Omakase, so we settled on a mix of nigiri and rolls.

Nigiri orders
chu-toro - soft and not too fatty
scallops - super soft. almost melts in the mouth.
uni - soft and creamy type. tastes extremely fresh

Roll orders
Crab roll - real fresh crab. Unagi on the inside was soft and not salty. tastes fantastic together. 
Scallop roll - comes topped with lots of scallops that taste good, but obviously not as good as the nigiri.

Service was excellent. They made sure we were confortable and even let us know that the nigiri would be coming slighty late.
author: Edward W.

description:
Came here with a friend to try out their omakase meal. It was my first time ordering omakase as it is quite an expense, and I must say, it was most certainly an amazing experience all throughout!

Tsubasa Sushi has a nice modern and clean look to it and very friendly service. They did an excellent job with the pacing of the meal and with explaining what each course included. With that said, let me go through what went down with the omakase meal.

Prologue: The Cubular Joy

The meal began with a humble cube of tofu, but with a slight twist. It was seasoned with some black sesame for a bit of sweetness to this cold dish. Loved it. 5/5

Chapter 1: The Snaptastic 4

So here we have the first four pieces of nigiri: flounder, char, snapper, and amberjack. The amberjack surprised me with it's surprising burst of flavor despite its light color. The char was also a highlight of these four as it had the skin in tact with some lovely fish oil. Good stuff. 5/5

Chapter 2: Chu Chu Chutoro

The meal moves on with another four piece of nigiri: scallop, chuutoro, flying fish, and mackeral. The scallop came in a nice chunky size and was the best scallop sashimi I've had on this side of the Pacific. The chuutoro was the easy winner here. The fatty tuna deliciousness that it is simply melts in the mouth for a timeless experience...... or so I thought because what came later proved me wrong. Aww yeah. 5/5

Bonus Chapter 1: NANI?!?!?! ... ... ... AAAAAAA~~~ SUGOI DESU NE!!!!!!

So we're pretty much halfway through the meal. If this were a novel, this is that part in the middle where they insert the pictures. Here, it is in color with 4K definition physical pages. The server comes and gives each of us a complimentary small bite of eggplant. It comes in a small bowl with a bit of broth beneath and a few sesame seeds sprinkled on top. At a first glance, it kinda comes off as being soggy and mushy like it has been soaking in a bath of something for too long despite it standing up as a solid entity. Looks are quite deceiving as this piece of eggplant was stupidly good. I legitimately was raving about it after the meal. Something about the flavor of the broth intertwined with the flavor of the tubular vegetable was just so right. Wowsers! 5/5

Chapter 3: The True Toro

And so the last set of nigiris arrive: wild cherry salmon, barracuda w/ uni, and toro. The wild cherry salmon was quite simply salmon on a whole 'nother level. The toro was quite simply fatty tuna on a whole 'nother level with its crazy melts in the mouth goodness unlike any other. The barracuda w/ uni was quite simply.... actually, I have no idea what a barracuda is or normally tastes like, but this was also super good with the buttery uni going in harmony with the savory fish. Best of the best! 5/5

Bonus Chapter 2: Chawhattawhattawhat?

When we ordered the omakase meal, we also decided to get an unagi chawanmushi appetizer. It's basically a cup of steamed egg with small pieces of eel mixed it. It was certainly good though difficult to share. The egg came out with a nice smooth and silky texture to make for a delicious cup of goodness though it all really paled in comparison to the omakase meal. Pretty good. 5/5

Chapter 4: Explosive Fireworks of Flavors

To end the meal before the dessert, a bowl filled with uni, ikura, and some greens were placed in front of each of us. Each bit of ikura would burst in the mouth with wonderful fish oil. Each sliver of uni was a buttery indulgence. The greens helped to tame the explosive flavors and went well between each bite. Yeahyuzz! 5/5

Epilogue: Sweet Sweet Plump Plump

The entire meal ended with a candied tomato per person. It comes in a bowl sitting on top of some sweet liquid. The skin has been pealed off, leaving but a clump of tomato meat. It's a nice bright red to look at and they add a little green thing on top as a decorative piece. It is sweet and sour like a typical tomato but with a higher emphasis on the sweet which really does make it taste like a candy but with an interesting texture. Nice! 5/5
author: Joshua M.

description:
Tsubasa's a solid option for a mid-tier omakase, cause sometimes you wanna #treatyoself to something special but you also want to be able to feed yourself for the rest of the month. More like a 4.5, but rounding up. 

Of course we had to go with the 12 piece nigiri omakase for $68. From the pictures you'd think that this place would cost an arm and a leg - nope! I was really impressed with the presentation, you can tell each slice, garnish, sprinkle was done with care. Everything on point. 

Here's what we got: 
1. Houbou (wild bluefin sea robin)
2. Iwana (artic char)
3. Madai (red snapper)
4. Kanpachi (amberjack)
5. Ma Saba (fresh Mackerel) - standout
6. Shirauo (wild ice fish) - this one was pretty unique since it was steamed 
7. Chu toro (bluefin tuna belly, medium fatty)
8. Muki hotate (fresh scallop)
9. Katsuo (bonito)
10. Uni kamasu (barracuda) - another one of the standouts
11. Toro (black fin tuna belly, fatty) - fatty melt in your mouth goodness with dat gold flake, omg
12. Ikura and uni

All seasoned already, so no soy sauce needed. There were a few standouts and a few we were 'meh' about (like the houbou which we thought was chewy). We also ordered akamutso (wild blue fish) a la carte at the end which was fuego. 

They have a very extensive selection of fish here, highly recommend if you want to try stuff you can't find at average sushi restaurants! So safe to say that Tsubasa is not yo average sushi restaurant.
author: Laverne N.

description: Got sick after eating here (2nd time) and it lasted a while. I just saw that their SF restaurant inspection is low (81) and they were dinged on 6/1/18 for (1) High risk food holding temperature, (2) Foods not protected from contamination, (3) Inadequate and inaccessible handwashing facilities, (4) Wiping cloths not clean or properly stored or inadequate sanitizer, (5) Unclean or degraded floors walls or ceiling. That explains why I got sick. Not acceptable, and even less acceptable for a Japanese restaurant serving raw fish where hygiene & quality control should be a top priority (good sushi restaurants usually have a score near 100). Other reviews mention a Chinese owner or sushi chefs. Sub-bar quality compared to Japanese sushi chefs who are meticulous about the fish & process. Too bad because we loved it the first time - but not worth getting sick. Old review: Fantastic sushi and excellent service. I'm extremely picky about sushi and only eat it if it's prepared by a Japanese chef (you know why if you have the same standards). We ordered nigiri from the special chef-recommended list that tells you where it comes from and all were great. Fresh. Great texture & flavor. Perfect seasoning (subtle and didn't need any soy sauce). The highlights: Baby Hamachi was OUTSTANDING. Loved the special miso soup with fish, which had rich flavor with ginger. Spicy tuna roll was good too. The service was great and everyone there so warm. We didn't have any wait to order or for food to arri. Perfect all around.
author: Ruth C.

description: Super fresh, super yummy! A lot of unique dishes that I didn't see in other Japanese restaurants.
author: Mei P.

description:
I came here during lunch for some delicious Chirashi which was $18. Everything else on the menu was pretty pricey.

The fish tasted extremely fresh and I heard they import their fish from Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo, which is pretty cool. It's probably one of the better places in SF for sushi. It's a pretty small place that was kind of busy when we were there for lunch, so I can imagine this placing being packed at dinner.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 5/5
Atmosphere: 4/5

While on a short trip to SF, we stayed very close to here, and I came here two nights in a row, it was that good. The first night, we were just walking by and decided to check it out, and they were able to seat us within 20 or so minutes, which was really great. We ordered the omakase, with some extra add-ons as well. I actually didn't like the omakase that much, but it is a relatively cheap one at around $70. It just felt like the order kept jumping around a lot, and could have been ordered better. However, if there is one thing I could recommend more than anything else, it would be the House Toro roll. It. Is. So. Good. SO GOOD. Wish I could eat it every day. But yeah, would recommend you stick to more rolls or ordering individual nigiri when dining here; it's rare that I would recommend the rolls over the nigiri at any sushi place, but I definitely think that's the play at Tsubasa.

Service could not be better, everyone is so courteous, and our water glasses were never low. Appreciated their attention and friendliness! A point off of atmosphere because the restaurant is a bit cramped at some points, you will definitely feel like a part of your neighbor's conversation.

tl;dr - Can't wait to go back for that house roll
author: Whitney G.

description:
We got the Sashimi omakase set + negitoro + AO ebi + muki hotate + king salmon nigiri + japanese uni + oburi toro + saba aburi.

What didn't go well: sashimi omakase. The pieces there were so bland and really had no flavor IMO. Things included was yellow jack, red snapper,... overall nothing fancy. I didn't enjoy it and felt like I wasted both money and stomach space.

Everything else was tasty. Will describe in order of my preference.

Uni: I'm trying to get into uni and this uni didn't have that much "pungency". Overall not that large and didn't really stand out IMO.

The hotate (scallops) was quite interesting. We got the sashimi version and there were 4 pieces. What I noticed were they were a bit firmer than some of my favorite ones. When I bit into it, it felt like there was no give. Maybe I just like mine a tiny bit chewier (those seem more fresh to me).

The saba aburi was mackereel with some finely grained radish on it. It seem like it was marinated in some sauce and maybe smoked a bit. The combination made for a really good bite.

Oburi toro: This was a hamatchi fish and it was interesting to see the fatty version of it. IMO, if you want a fatty fish, just get the fatty tuna. It was tasty no doubt, but when I know what the bar is for the fatty tuna, it just couldn't quite hit that one.

AO Ebi: The deep fried head was really good. I didn't think it was deep fried so much that all you get is crunch, and you can really taste the meat in the head (which I enjoyed). At the same time, the whiskers??? were crunchy so there was a nice balance. The actual shrimp itself I thought could've been a little bit more raw. They cook it a bit I think (3 seconds). I'm used to and prefer when it's more slippery and raw. 

Top 2

King salmon: Just great salmon. It wasn't a fatty cut, but it really did taste a little fatty. It was so soft to bite/chew. Wish I got more of these.

Oshizushi Negitoro: wow this was good. It was a layer of fatty tuna (seared at the top, raw at the bottom) on top of a layer of rice. Really enjoyed the combination of seared + raw as well as the radish that's provided for it. Knew the tuna was superrrr fatty and the rice helped to make it easier to go down since it helped balance the fatty part.

Along the way they gave some free snacks: some crab samples + marinated eggplant + sweeted tomato.

Stick to the "main" things and not the generic items and you'll be happy here.
author: Victor D.

description:
Wow! I don't get impressed by restaurants very often, but I was thoroughly surprised by this restaurant. The fish here was unexpectedly fresh and high quality for how much they cost.

Our table of 8 ordered the following for the table: 12 bottles of sake, a ton of appetizers, 12 piece omakase for each person, multiple rounds of uni and masu, and a bunch of other stuff. The thing that stood out to me was how incredibly fresh the fish was. The few that stood out include the uni, masu, and hamachi. The masu was one of the best I've eaten because it was ridiculously fatty, and I'm pretty sure I ordered at least 6 pieces for myself.

The service was a little bit slow, but we did order omakase for a ridiculous amount of people, and the quality was worth the wait. I'll definitely be coming to this place in the future.
author: Kevin C.

description: Thick fishhh, little rice combo. And a mouthwatering wagyu (my bf said that). I did a DIY omakase order. In other words, I ordered each nigiri myself after I wasn't impress with their omakase list. Get: Salmon both wild Alaskan and the regular salmon. Otoro (fatty) with the gold shimmers. Hamachi from JP. Wagyu!
author: Proud C.

description: Reel sushi restaurant. Tako ashi (raw octpus) was a real surprise. Uni was interesting , good though. The taste of sushi rice is perfect. The ratio of the rice and the fish is great. This is the place I will return for sure.
author: Lydia L.

description: How did this restaurant even get such high reviews....we ordered omakase and we had to wait about 30 mins between each dish....it was torturous! We all started watching YouTube...how were we supposed to enjoy the food at all when we ended up just wanting to chunk down any food just to fill our stomachs...finally the picture is my water, which never gotten refilled even once during our painful 2 hour wait...Make sure you download a few movies and bring your own drink before deciding to come here!
author: Leo L.

description:
Where do I even begin? One of the best miso soups I've had is from this place.

Their lunch bentos are top notch but their sushi is even better. The bluefin tuna are so damn good.

I got the two specials: chu-toro tataki & oshizushi negitoro.

Considering they are both made with bluefin tuna, I assume the "specials" at Tsubasa just indicate that they are new dishes the chef wanted to show off that day and not exactly a limited quantities type of special. Regardless both were very tasty. Everything was seasoned properly and the fish just melted in my mouth. Ugh I am getting hungry writing this. If you're in the area and craving sushi, I would highly recommend this place.
author: David K.

description:
I sat at the sushi bar and had an omakase dinner. All the sushi pieces were nice but not very memorable. 
The three sushi chefs were very casual, joking around and throwing the fish pieces around.
The wait staff were very sweet and attentive
author: Renin J.

description: Woah - best sushi find in the city - for real. The lines can be long (make a reservation - they're very accommodating!) but it's a 100% worth it. We did a no-shellfish omakase and it was truly incredible. They brought it out 4 pieces at a time over the course of an hour and each nigiri was better than the previous bite. Incredible presentation and even better taste. They also gave us the yummiest sweet tomatoes (sounds odd but was so good) to finish the meal. I'm definitely coming back here to try the rolls!
author: Sam M.

description:
Updated review:

We dined at Tsubasa again for dinner and as always, the meal was delicious. We dont typically order anymore since we trust in Wilsons recommendations. Omakase is always the best way to go here! 

My two favorite fishes of the night were kanpachi and ma saba. Both very thick but so delicious! Rule of thumb- always order uni last. 

Chef Wilson numbed our tongues before giving us the exceptionally fresh fish. The food is always incredible here, but I would definitely say that chef Wilson is the main reason I continue coming here and referring my friends and family here. During our meals, he is very friendly and always gives us recommendations on the freshest fish options. He teaches us about the different types of fish and preparation. I come here 20% for the food, but 80% for the experience and Wilson makes my experience worth it every time. 

Read below to learn about what we ordered: 

- Sesame tofu
- Zensai sanshu - right to left in picture yamakake, ikura oroshi, ankimo
- Omakase:
- Shiro dai kobujime - White snapper marinated in kelp from japan
- Iwana - artic charr
- Kanpachi - Amberjack from Japan - OH MY GOSH!! So good! 
- Ma saba - wild fresh mackerel from japan - also really good!
- Sakura masu - wild cherry salmon from japan
- Nasu agedashi 
- Chu-toro - black fin tuna belly 
- Muki hotate - fresh scallop from japan
- Sumi ika - wild cuttlefish from japan
- Suma-gatsuo - wild skipjack bonito from Japan
- Uni kamasu - wild barracuda with uni from japan
- Toro - black fin tuna belly fatty 
- Fried barracuda
- Shimaaji - yellow jack from japan
- Mirugai - live giant clam 
- Atsuyaki - blue shrimp soft sponge cake
- Uni ikura - always a must to end your meal!


------------------------------------------------

Tsubasa does not ever disappoint. 

We came and dined for dinner and had to have the omakase. See below for more details of our visit. 

- sesame tofu 
- 1. Onagadai kobujime - Red snapper from japan
- 2. Iwana- Artic charr, canada
- 3. Hiramasa - wild king fish from japan
- 4. Sagoshi- Baby spanish mackarel, japan - stronger flavor
- 5. Ankimo umi masu - ocean trout, scotland topped with monkfish liver
- 6. Kanpachi- Amberjack, japan
- Nasu agedashi- fried eggplant in sweet broth, chilled
- 7. Chu toro- med blue fin tuna belly 
- 8. Muki-hotate - fresh scallop- yaaaaaas!!! 
- 9. Managatsuo - wild star butterfish , japan - melts in your mouth but texture is not very smooth, rough
- 10. Kamasu- Barracuda topped with sea urchin
- 11. Toro - black fin tuna belly, fatty, - another one of my favorites!
- 12. Ishimochi - white wild croaker, japan
- Oshizushi- negi toro pressed roll
- 13. Uni

The attention to detail the chefs take to prepare the sushi is notable. They really pour their heart into preparing each dish. 

The servers at night were different than the lunchtime servers. All of the wait staff was attentive and friendly and even better than the ones during the lunch hour. 

I am elated with my experience dining here once again, and for dinner for the first time. I love sitting at the bar and watching the chefs work their magic. 

We always have great conversation and learn so much about the various kinds of fish from Wilson. He makes our experience worth 5 stars and the reason why we continue referring our friends and family here.
author: Claire W.

description:
This was a little biased rating. I came here with really good company so I feel like I naturally had a good memory associated with this place. 

First of all, service is SPECTACULAR. I scored a last minute reservation online and when I arrived 15 minutes early, they sat me at the bar (as I had requested) where two seats have been reserved for me and my friend. That was nice that they honored the reservation and didn't make me wait around. Please make reservations... I saw so many people with party of 2 being told they need to wait for over an hour. Service continued to be super great throughout the night. Kept my glass of plum wine full and tea also.

Onto the food. We both got the 12 piece omakase nigiri for $75 each. Hm. I think first off, the sushi rice was very well done. Great flavor, perfectly cooked grains, not too cold or warm, cohesive under the fish and didn't fall apart when I picked it up. The fish are all super fresh, and all of them are given to you with seasoning already, so no need to mix your own soy sauce concoction. However, I think most of the fish was overpowered by ponzu or citrus. A few pieces were dressed with ponzu, so my tongue is hit with lemon aggressively when I first put the fish in my mouth. One was dressed with lime zest, so that was very strong also. I would've rather tasted more of the fish itself. My favorites were the scallop and charred baraccuda with uni on top. Ugh so good! The scallop flesh was firm and definitely not previously frozen or soaked in salt water. They end the meal with a dish that combines uni with marinaded ikura. That was like the masterpiece of the ocean. The marinaded ikura were a tad salty since they didn't have rice to support it, but it was so good. Other fish were not very memorable but still good. I remember my fatty Toro broke into a few pieces when the chef served it to me, that was kind of... Yeah. I also felt like they could've ended the meal with the tamago, but instead they served this skinless plum tomato stewed in syrup. Very interesting... 

We also got the pressed fatty tuna sushi - that was good but I don't think it's worth $19 for 7 pieces. But then again, this place is pretty pricey, so that's actually not very expensive in comparison to other things on the menu. 

At the end of the meal, we were still hungry. Yep.... This is why I docked off a star. If I come in and choose omakase, I expect to be at least not hungry but the end of the meal. They couldve supplemented the meal with something like miso soup or salad in the beginning, or maybe even just more of that eggplant that they served one piece of in the middle of the meal. 

We paid $115 per person including a drink each (including tips). Not bad but ... We had to go to McDonald's afterwards to eat more. But overall, we had a great experience. The sushi chefs explained each piece and I felt very taken care of here.
author: Susanna C.

description:
Tsubasa is my favorite sushi place in the Hayes Valley area. Fresh sushi, good attention to detail, and good service. I've been able to stop by at 5:30pm on a Friday and get seated w/o any wait. I ordered oshizushi neigitoro (pressed negi toro roll), negi hama roll (yellow tail w/green onions), futomaki (jumbo roll), kurodai (black sea bream), and some fresh chopped wasabi (awesome that they had this...)

Expect about $50-60 for food per person. Service is very attentive, and the place has a good atmosphere.
author: James S.

description: Great food and reasonable corkage.  Instead of ordering the omakasa we order a bunch of random pieces which was great .
author: Shirley V.

description:
I can't say I enjoyed my stay here. I came here for lunch with a friend after our work out. But felt totally ignored. From the beginning, it took them forever to just get our initial order. When we asked for water, it didn't come until we asked again... We asked for a box and the woman said yes... Only to ask another waiter and he said, "no take out". It would've been great if the waiter just told us in the beginning. We were literally confused and irritated the whole time. I wasn't sure if it was a language barrier, but this waiter could have at least talked to someone who did understand to talk to us?? There were about 5 people to working and about 5 tables to serve. We really did not understand the slowness and lack of customer service there at all. How does this place have great reviews??

The food was decent... I guess. I got the negi toro donburi and a salmon handroll.  The toro was mashed and served over rice with the negi sprinkled on top. It also has the wasabi on the side. My friend ordered the chirashi bowl. She really liked the quality of her fish. I felt that the shitty service distracted me from the taste of my food. You could say it left a bad taste in my mouth.
author: Lyra C.

description: Chef Peter and Chef John are THE MEN!! My party of four got seated immediately for our 8:00pm reservation right at the sushi bar. All four of us opted for the omakase. Peter (who has notable sushi experience in the restaurant business) made sure to get our likes, dislikes and allergies before creating our amazing, delicious, aesthetically pleasing, fresh, (need I say more?!) tastings. Each omakase was personalized and beautifully presented. The chefs were both incredibly friendly and sociable. It was like hanging out with old friends paired with a phenomenal and delectable experience. Will definitely be back!
author: Annie N.

description:
The sushi here was sooo good! My boyfriend made a reservation and we came here for my birthday. We got the 12 piece omakase for ~$68 each. The service was very polite and they explained each piece of sushi.  

My favorites were the fatty tunas and salmon... to be expected. The fatty tuna came with gold shavings! The nigiri is so flavorful that you don't need soy sauce, and  the fish just melts in your mouth. Mmm. They also serve extra sides with the omakase; we got some black bean tofu thing, and this eggplant dish. 

Because it was my birthday, we got free green tea ice cream with a lit candle! The ice cream was really good and also comes with homemade mochi. I think the 12 piece omakase is alright for satisfying hunger, but we did get another dragon roll on top of it. Just don't go in starving... Overall, A+ experience and sushi!!! I already want to go back.
author: Wendy D.

description:
O h m y g o d. It doesn't get any better than this.

I made a reservation on Yelp so I could come here for dinner on my birthday. Boyfriend and I got the 12 piece nigiri omakase ($80 each) for ourselves and the ika geso (tempura fried squid legs) to share. All the nigiri pieces were SO good and the variety was very well balanced. The last piece was uni with salmon roe on top of a bed of microgreens and a shiso leaf and h o l y m o l y it was one of the best things I've ever eaten. It was so good, my boyfriend ordered another one for us. The uni was definitely the best way to finish off a great meal...

But WAIT, there's more! We got the following on the house: 2 pieces of A5 wagyu beef nigiri, 1 uni (they charged for my boyfriend, but not me), 2 oysters on a half shell, extra pieces of toro placed next to the toro nigiri that were part of the omakase, a taster glass of sparkling sake, refreshing candied tomato dessert, AND a medley of black sesame custard, green tea custard, house-made mochi, and red bean paste. I could've sworn the chef who served the toro nigiri put more gold flakes on my piece LOL.

Even without the birthday perks, Tsubasa Sushi effortlessly earned itself a spot on my list of favorite places in SF. With high quality fish that won't break your wallet, it's a must try.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Quite an overdue review, but I had an amazing omakase here a couple months ago. The fish was incredibly fresh, service was on point, and the price was incredibly reasonable. 

My bf and I had a great conversation with Chef Wilson, the owner of Tsubasa, which started funny enough from us not eating something he had sent out. He sent his recommendation - ankimo aka monkfish liver - and both of us had had that before and neither of us had liked it. We decided to give it a bite but sadly it still wasn't working its magic. The server brought it back in and Chef Wilson saw and asked if we didn't enjoy it and actually sent out another item for us to try, which we liked significantly better - I believe it was their homemade seaweed dish, which we loved. It was super refreshing. 

My bf and I also enjoyed the uni and salmon roe dish. It was a perfect medley of textures, flavors and a good play on uni that we hadn't seen at other omakases. We ordered a couple extra sushi rolls, which were delicious too. We will definitely be back to enjoy omakase and see Chef Wilson. I HIGHLY recommend if you're looking for a delicious omakase that won't break the bank!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
Another solid omakase spot, right in the center of Hayes Valley. Reservations here are easy to make on Yelp, I was able to book a 8pm seating on a weekday a couple days prior to going. The interior of the restaurant felt really homey and everyone working there was extremely friendly. 

We ordered the 12 piece nigiri omakase, which I will have to say is ridiculously well priced at around $70pp, and a bottle of sake. Our sushi chef, John, was super awesome and gave us really thorough descriptions of the different varieties of sake and let us sample a bunch before we found one we really liked. All of the fish at Tsubasa was extremely fresh, and John was very fun and entertaining throughout our meal. My favorite pieces would have to be the wagyu nigiri, bluefin tuna toro belly, hotate, and the uni. 

Overall, the omakase here is well worth it considering the price point and quality of the fish. Be sure to sit at the bar!
author: Angela K.

description:
I'm really not sure why reviews are so high here. We did omakase at the counter and for sure it is very reasonably priced for the amount of food we got, but that should've been a clue to how good the quality would be.

I was highly disappointed by the sushi, the chefs are Chinese...which is fine but it just wasn't authentic. I'm not sure what I was expecting really. I wouldn't come here again. Also it's a dead zone for cell reception for whatever reason. I'm sad I couldn't like this place more.
author: Stine H.

description:
Since it was half empty, and we didn't have much time before going to the show at SF Jazz Center, we decided to give a shot, although I'm a bit suspicious about Japanese restaurants in SF in general. 
My comment is only for sushi as we didn't order anything else - it was surprisingly good for the price.  Our server was attentive, and we didn't wait at all like other reviews mentioned.
author: M G.

description:
I made reservations online for 530 on Sunday. 
I came here 2 hr earlier in order to find a parking space. Luckily, found a spot just in front of the restaurant. 

The service is pretty good. when we arrive, the waitress took us to the window seat which i really like. 
The service is pretty good. waitresses are polite and patient.
the tea is pretty good
for the appetizer, i ordered ankimo and mochi. 

mochi is surprisingly good. 
ankimo has a very strong smell...

For nigiri, 
I ordered scallop, a5 beef, uni, salmon, otoro 
The otoro is kind of disappointing. the smell is a little bit strong which makes me feel it's not that fresh. 

A5 beef is AMAZING. super delicious, soft. It has a little butter with it. 
Uni is good. 
scallop and salmon are just standard. 


Overall, I feel the nigiri here is not as good as the one I got in Wako. They are just not like authentic nigiri but it's kind of expensive.That's why i gave it 3 star. But the service and environment are pretty good.
author: Tina H.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Thursday night and the omakase was spectacular and it was a lot cheaper than comparable omakase in other spots around the city. The omakase sashimi bowl was great as well and did not lack quality fish. The toro was amazing and completely melted in my mouth and the steamed egg appetizer was incredible. 

The location of the restaurant is also great so there are a ton of places to walk around before or after your meal. Will definitely be coming back!
author: Norman S.

description:
Love love love Tsubasa Sushi! 

The staff, everyone from front of house to back of house, is so friendly and knowledgeable. They really make our visits memorable. And the sushi! Oh my! Absolutely delicious. My boyfriend and I like to try something new every time we go out for sushi and this place never fails to impress. They will recommend absolutely delicious items and then tell us all about them. They even have several off menu secrets (I'm divulging those secrets because you just need to ask for yourself and, well, they are limited. I don't want them gone on my next visit ). Everything is always delicious, fresh, and a cut above the rest!

So, I could go on forever about how wonderful this place is, or, y'all can go try it for yourselves.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I couldn't believe I got to go see Hamilton two weekends in a row! Since the theatre is nearby and it's been like how many weeks ago (?) I visited Tsubasa, I decided to have dinner there.  It was last minute that I found out I will be going to see Hamilton so it was too late to make a reservation.  I made sure to get to the resto before they open so I can get a table, eat and go in about an hour before the show.  

Didn't have enough time for an omakase so went with a la cart.  Chef Wilson, Peter, and Tom took really good care of us and made my sat night that much more special so thank you so much!

Definitely the luckiest girl that day!
author: Shirley H.

description:
Tsubasa is worth all its stars. If you're deciding between O-toro, Domo, or here, definitely go for Tsubasa. The sushi is authentic and fresh, service is great, and the seating areas aren't too cramped. 

Yes you can make a reservation on Yelp (and I highly recommend that you do) but a lot of times they say they're no more reservations left but when I call they tell me to just walk in with no wait. 

I know some people said they never pick up their phones but I haven't had an issue with that. 

If you're a salmon love, they have a few great salmon options (juicy scallop roll, salmon about roll).

Edit: Very shady, they will add 18% automatic tip if you have a party of 5 (usually it's 6 or more anywhere else). This "policy" is not written on the menu anywhere. Then the signature receipt comes and they will suggest you tip again on the bottom, suggesting 18% as the lowest amount when other similar places start the suggestion at 15%. But why even include that when you've already added the tip yourself?
author: Ming Y.

description:
Binky and I came here to celebrate our anniversary last month. It was the night before Thanksgiving and there were still a good number of families/couples eating! I was kinda surprised since it was so close to the holidays.

Binky and I wanted to do the omakase and set a reservation for it. Unfortunately, the restaurant seated us at a table instead of the bar. Looking back, I wish we had simply asked for the bar because the omakase was N O T the same at the table (they just bring you the fish in portions of 4, 4, 3, 1). Another couple got to sit at the bar and they did the traditional omakase (w the chef preparing/handing you fish one at a time)!! 

Nevertheless, the sushi was AMAZING. Each fish was already seasoned w salt/lemon/wasabi/etc. so there really was no need to alter it in any way. Binky and I were BLOWN AWAY with each new fish presented. My fave was 100% the one w the scallop on top -- YUM. We also got a complimentary oyster. Plating was beautiful and I was decently full after the meal.

I saw someone order the chirashi here and it looked beautiful as well. I think I'd be back just to try it! :)
author: Christine H.

description:
Came here with 6:30 reservations on Saturday, but the boyfie forgot to ask for sushi bar seating =_= Fortunately, the chef was fine with us sitting there. We both opted for the 12 pc $60 omakase nigiri set, but was told there would be a slight wait as the chef was backed up. While we were waiting we ordered the albacore tataki as well as the ankimo. Both were delicious!

We were both pleasantly surprised with how fresh and delicious all the nigiri's were... flavors were amazing and each piece sent us to sushi heaven. To be honest, I like this place more than a lot of higher end sushi joints in the city... INCLUDING Kusakabe and Maruya. Way more casual, but not run down like Zushi Puzzle. Our sushi chef Wilson was very informative and accommodating. He noticed we were really enjoying more of the fatty fish so he was nice enough to keep it coming. Thank you, Chef Wilson :)


I've been recommending this place left and right. So happy with our dinner :) Hope the quality doesn't go down... which I highly doubt because Chef Wilson really seemed to care about each piece of nigiri.

P.S. The uni and ikura was SOOOOOOOOOOOOO damn good. One of the best I've ever had. Just WOW.
author: Anna M.

description: So disappointed but it didn't live up to the hype. Service was very very slow. We had to talk to the manager to speed things up. Fish including the specials are not fresh. Have been to much better restaurants at lower prices. Not sure why the rating was so high. It looks like the place was not staffed by Japanese staff
author: Vivi W.

description:
If I could give this place 7 stars I would. AMAZING. We ordered appetizers, sashimi, nigiri, sake, and 8 pc.  Omakase.  Nothing disappointed, extremely fresh from Japan, and terrific service. Sit at the bar to see all the action. Soy and ponzu are both made in house. 

For the details: We had toro (fatty and medium grades), black kingfish, sailfin poacher, sea robin, yellowtail (2 types), monkfish liver, scallop (two types), tamago, edamame, STASH roll, bread pudding for dessert and a few different sakes. 

While at the bar, all questions to the chefs were answered and you can tell they're enthusiastic about their service and customers. 

Pricing is extremely reasonable.  Our entire meal was a tad under $200 and would've easily cost $300+ in Houston (home).
author: John H.

description: I have been here back in March, but decided to write this review to be their 300th reviewer! Tsubasa and Hinata are two of my favorite omakase places in SF so far, due to price and quality. I feel that with Tsubasa's omakase, they give you everything you need and want without having to order the ones you want from the a la carte menu! Hinata is great but in order to have those specialty fishes, you have to add an additional $30 to your order. But in Tsubasa, they filter out the filler fishes and go straight into it! I had a great experience here for my bday, they gave us additional courses as well, so of course I am instantly going to fall in love with this place! Now I just booked another reservation for this Sunday for my 1 year anniversary as my bf is very new to the omakase scene. I am excited!! :)
author: Celine L.

description:
We are on a mission to try as many sushi restaurants in the city as possible. After two amazing omakase experiences and one trip to Japan, we opted for an affordable option and chose Tsubasa. So worth it!

We ordered the $68, 12pcs Nigiri omakase and 2 rolls, and got super fresh, nice chunks of fish! Flavors are unique and the appetizers were delicious as well. My favorites - Hotate and Otoro. Not a fan of the sweet tomato you get with the check. Super friendly service, would definitely recommend!
author: Shay N.

description:
You should definitely not go here and ruin my new favorite sushi spot in SF. You won't be able to just walk in at 830p on a Friday and get a table for two at the counter. The nigiri omakase won't be outstanding, the uni will melt all over your mouth, and you'll probably leave feeling way too satisfied for it to be worth your time and money.

I repeat: Don't. Go. Here!
author: Navi O.

description:
Summary: The quality of fish was decent for the price point, but each piece came painfully slow (2.5 hrs to serve 8 pieces of nigiri) despite the restaurant being less than 50% full, and the chefs were shockingly rude to the point where it felt threatening (slammed plates while staring our table down and cursing loudly at us in a mixture of Japanese and English after we politely asked the waiter if it was possible to cancel the rest of our order). 

The chefs clearly gave preferential treatment to guests who appeared to be friends, while neglecting the rest of the customers (including us) to the point where it took 2.5 hours to serve 8 pieces of nigiri... By that time, it was already past 10pm (on a Sunday night) so we politely asked to see if we could cancel the rest of the orders if possible. At this point, I was just slightly disappointed by the slow service, but that was apparently the tip of the iceberg. Once the waiter went back to inform one of the chefs, the chef erupted in anger, yelling in a mix of Japanese & English and slamming a few plates. Naturally, I was startled, so I turned around (my back had been against the sushi bar) to see what the commotion was about - that was when I noticed the chef staring us down while continuing to mutter (unclear what he was saying though). At this point in the night, all of the guests had already left the bar, which means the death glare went on for about 2-3 minutes before the waiter came back with the check while apologizing for what was happening. I am honestly speechless from how horrendous this whole experience has been and will warn my friends and family to stay away from this establishment.
author: Carpus T.

description:
Absolutely fantastic. Everything we had was great- and we ate A LOT. I will dream of the Toro Kama that I ate & the a5 wagyu. The chef Peter is an awesome guy and makes incredible sushi. His style is unique and top top quality. 

I recommend getting the 12 piece Nigiri. It's priced at $80 but it is more than a meal- it is an experience. 

Hands down the best sushi I've ever had. This meal is in my top 3 most memorable meals of my life.
author: Roman K.

description:
Found this place through the social media platform, Instagram. I was very intrigued when there's a new Omakase near by. We immediately reserved bar seating for 2 with Yelp for the the coming Saturday, November 19 at 6pm. 

We were worried about parking but we found parking about a block away and walked over. The restaurant is located the same side of Monsieur Benjamin on Gough St. but across the small intersection. 

Entered and gave my name for the reservation and was seated immediately at the bar with menus.
