We opted for the Omakase 12 pieces set - $60/pp. We were kind of skeptical about the quality with such low price tag for a Omakase in the city. We also ordered a Japanese beer, hot tea and water for drinks. 

We started off with an appetizer which was included in the meal that we didn't know. After that, we were served with plates of three pieces of nigiri one after another until we have the 11 pieces as promised on the menu. We were also asked if we would like to order any other nigiri before the finale, 12th piece course - Uni. We order two additional orders of nigiri that was recommended by the waiter. While plates of nigiri were served to us by different waiters and the chef never actually had the chance to introduce himself to us. They were very busy making the sushi on their side. I wish there were a bit more interaction so I can learn more about them. 

The quality of the fish superb but some lack presentation. Would definitely recommend this place for the inexpensive price tag for a good Omakase meal.
author: Maria H.

description: Peter is an incredible chef and always takes the best care of his diners. It was an incredible experience, and the sushi itself tasted very fresh and delicious. I will be back many times!
author: Alanna P.

description:
The first thing I wanted to eat when I landed in San Francisco was some fresh sushi.

My friend suggested we go to Tsubasa, and I'm glad we did. We got there pretty early (right when they opened actually), and we could see how this place gets packed during lunchtime.

We ordered the chef's special, which were two beautiful platters of sashimi followed by sushi.

Every single bite was a delicious surprise, and I was only looking forward to the next. Don't forget to eat the gari too! So, so good.

The wait staff could have been a little more attentive, and could have come by without us trying to hunt them down, but other than that it was a positive experience.
author: Zarene S.

description:
Very good fish .pretty reasonable price for that aria 
Service are great !!
I will come back .
author: Jenna K.

description:
Tsubasa Sushi replaces The One sushi bar space in the heart of Hayes Valley right by Gough and Hayes Streets. And frankly, it's much better than what The One used to be. We were able to snag a reservation the day before, which is rare these days, and were extremely happy with our meal. The fish was fresh and displayed solid knife work, the service was attentive and helpful, and the overall meal experience was solid. (My real rating is probably 4.5/5, but rounded up!)

Tsubasa specializes in more traditional sushi; we stuck primarily to sashimi and nigiri, but has some unique takes on their traditional options. If you're looking for super creative, fancy rolls or nigiri options, I would probably go elsewhere like Elephant Sushi or Umami. It's also not the place you bring a big group and do sake bombs. But I would highly recommend Tsubasa for a centrally located traditional sushi dinner that isn't outrageously expensive; other favorites in the same range include Saru Sushi, Eiji, and Kabuto Sushi.

You can skip the appetizers in the future -- we tried: a maguro (tuna) sunomono salad which is a marinated cucumber salad with seaweed, and a trio which consisted of shirataki (yam) noodles, a combo of tororo (mountain yam paste), tuna, and wasabi, and house cured ikura (salmon roe). Everything was fine, but didn't particularly wow except for that ikura. So ridiculously good! Not sure if they cured it in sake or something else, but the roe was slightly sweet and not briny at all, and burst in our mouths like mini firecrackers. 

The 10-piece sashimi omakase served with its own house-made soy sauce was a great deal. The omakase was served all at once on a plate to our table and  actually ended up being 15 pieces as they provided 3 of each kind of fish instead 2. Everything was fresh, well-cut, and they were thoughtful in the progression from the light-tasting maguro (tuna) and ending with the more pungent aji (mackerel). And I typically am not a huge aji fan, but their version was perfectly cured and not fishy at all. The aji and the iwana (arctic char) were my favorite sashimi items, although all were great.

Their nigiri was also solid. The vinegar in the rice was slightly stronger than I typically prefer but the grains were just the right amount of stickiness, and each piece of nigiri was perfectly sauced and balanced. Their specialties like the zuwai-gani (snow crab) served with kani miso (crab guts), hotate (scallop), seared ibodai (butterfish), and uni (sea urchin) with ikura. All were incredible. Hotate perhaps was the least creative or interesting of the ones we tried, but still delicious. The seared ibodai nigiri came a dab of their house cured beet root on top, which was the perfect acidic and texture balance to the soft, buttery texture of the fish. And the uni nigiri when consumed with the same amazing ikura from the starter was a party in my mouth.

Throughout the night, service was attentive (but not too much so), and they even provided complimentary appetizer (a green tea tofu if I remember correctly), palate cleanser, and a little dessert (sweet potato). Tsubasa definitely won my heart that night, I would place it high on the sushi considerations for the city.

Read more about the meal on my blog: http://www.vcinthekitchen.com/tsubasa-sushi-sf/
author: Vic C.

description:
Some of the best sushi I've had here in the states. I have been by this wonderful spot many times and wondered if the what turned out to be excellent Japanese cuisine was true. 
Tonight I jumped into the wonderfulness of traveling to Osaka in an instant. 
Fresh and tasty sushi prepared exactly as I remember in Japan. The style of  preparation is uncompressed! The staff are friendly and make you feel very welcome. 
I definitely have this wonderful spot bookmarked!
author: Bruce B.

description:
THIS IS HANDS DOWN THE BEST SUSHI IVE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE. If you're going to splurge and treat yo' self, this is the BEST place to do it. The chef, Peter, took extremely great care of us by recommending his favorite fishes. Every piece I had was a solid 20/10 score. Everything good you've heard about this place is true. 

This place is rightfully pricey. Top dollar for top quality food. I 100% recommend making this your go-to sushi spot whenever you have a special occasion. You really feel like royalty eating here from the gold flakes on top of the fish to the rare toro kama that melts in your mouth. I'll be dreaming of this food until I have it again.
author: Dana S.

description:
Since my last visit a month and a half ago I was dying to go back to Tsubasa for dinner and finally made it in last week. I was super excited to try the very reasonably priced omakase ($60) but, after reviewing the menu I decided to piece together my adventure. 

I started with some pieces of nigiri: 

Aji - lightly glazed with soy and a firm fatty fish. Not for beginner sushi eaters. 

Ikura - might be my favorite nigiri on the planet. I'm a sucker for any kind of fish egg and their house cured salmon roe is stupendous. Also not for beginners. 

I'm normally not the kind of person who orders a bunch of rolls but, they looked so appealing that night so I got a couple. The spicy tuna/asparagus roll topped with albacore was super light and naturally had a nice crunch. The highlight of the "rolls" was the pressed box nigiri. It's kind of like a roll without any nori (see picture). It was topped with toro and had fresh wasabi you could add to each piece...none of that fake green stuff :) 

I'll let the pictures speak for themselves as the fish is really good here and at the perfect price point for San Francisco. It's now my go-to spot for casual, yet elevated fish. Service with a smile and a short/solid saké list to boot.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Good and affordable omakase in Hayes Valley. I love eating at the sushi bar and interacting with the chefs! 12 piece omakase -- thanks chef for throwing in a couple extra pieces!
author: Christine C.

description: My first time and not my last! Looking for parking is a pain in the butt! Took us almost an hour to even park. Tip , find parking somewhere... take Lyft over to the restaurant for sure.  Service is great, very friendly, attentive and answered all my questions. I ordered the Omakase and everything was so fresh and delicious .
author: Cynthia K.

description:
Absolutely delicious rolls and sushi. I'm not a big sushi eater, but I will admit that the rolls were on point. Some of the best I've tried in the city! 

Service was very quick and courteous as well. Jackson was our server and was extremely social and welcoming. Their welcome amenity was delicious and this felt like a Michelin Star restaurant regarding quality, service, and food taste.

Would visit again. Great job Jackson!
author: Albert K.

description:
Got the Omakase with a friend, and it was one of the best things I've done on a Friday night!

Just sit, and be pampered with each carefully crafted piece of nigiri. 

Each fish was super tasty and fresh! The toro was super soft and fatty. No ragrats!

Service is nice and attentive. We ordered more items after the omakase, and they had no problem with that! (I wished the nigiri were bigger, since they were smaller than I had expected)

10/10 would recommend!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Great great sushi 
Then service was great food was as described And the price was fair 

Would return with family
author: Paula O.

description: Came here on Friday night with reservations at 8pm. The first thing I noticed was the fishy smell when I walked in. The sushi is quite good but the service was so uneven and took way too long. Perhaps they focused on the bar patrons more rather than the tables but for a half filled restaurant that late at night I was a bit baffled why our meal took over 2 hours. We would get two nigiris then had to wait another 30 minutes for the next two nigiris. We remained hungry throughout the meal and couldn't even truly enjoy the food (which was quite tasty). I really didn't understand why they made two nigiris at a time... just make my whole order if it's going to take forever. This was a complete 180 from the service we received the first time we went to Tsubasa. Not sure what went wrong but it was extremely disappointing.
author: Cathy B.

description:
This place has an elegant and classy atmosphere. It is on the pricier side, but the quality of the fish is fresh and excellent. 

I came here on a Saturday night. It wasn't crowded at all, but they did ask if we had reservations. Service was very friendly. We decided to try a couple nigiri items and a roll. We had the chu toro, medai, kanpachi, arctic char, king salmon, and an avocado salmon roll. Everything was extremely fresh and seasoned already with wasabi and sauce so no need for extra soy sauce. 

This is a very cute atmosphere for a date.
author: Christina G.

description:
Sitting across the alley from Monsieur Benjamin and taking over for the clubby, decidedly mediocre sushi spot that preceded it (The One), this modestly decorated sushi restaurant was actually working from a deficit position when it opened. I wasn't even thinking about trying it until we noticed that there would be a wait at Little Gem. Impatient locals that we are, Jamie W. and I bee-lined over here thinking we would grab a bit of sushi. Sure enough, there was plenty of space in here for lunch, so we parked our arses at one of the high-top tables near the window.

Jamie decided on the $11 California Roll Bento Box, which was simply six pieces of maki, a little tempura, a little salad, and an unnecessary scoop of rice given the aforementioned California Roll (photo: http://bit.ly/1tlXPu4). It was pretty good actually, but mine reflected more of the chef's touch, a $16 Chirashi Donburi Bowl with an eclectic collection of sliced fresh fish, roe, grated daikon, and watermelon radishes over rice that was quite delicious (photo: http://bit.ly/1UGttut). Along with a hearty bowl of miso soup, it made for the ideal lunch. We were impressed enough to come back for dinner about six weeks later. The rest of the neighborhood finally showed up since it was buzzing. Word-of-mouth must have spread.

While waiting for Jamie to arrive, I went ahead and ordered the $10 Ankimo because I am a sucker for fresh monkfish liver in ponzu sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1OfO75H). It had such a lush flavor and was very fresh-tasting. Jamie arrived too late to enjoy the ankimo, bu we ordered the $13 Rainbow Roll straight away, and it was hearty with a fresh crab avocado filling and covered with all the requisite fish in a mosaic fashion (photo: http://bit.ly/1UFVsHW). The $7 Mixed Tempura plate came next with a nice blend of shrimp, asparagus and eggplant slices lightly battered accompanied by a light dipping sauce and sea salt (photo: http://bit.ly/1YhmAms).

A couple of more creative rolls followed. First was the familiar and well-executed $10 Spider Roll with deep-fried soft-shell crab, cucumber, and avocado (photo: http://bit.ly/25ONx6C). The second was the idiosyncratic $13 Holy Crab Roll with freshwater eel combined with avocado, topped with crab and drizzled with a spicy & sweet sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1tfKzq8). Delicious with a saucy decadence. We could see how Tsubasa could become our go-to sushi spot, especially since Jamie has turned Japanese since our last trip to Tokyo. It's true. Pretty soon he'll start bowing when we meet up and maybe wear slip-on shoes before he goes through TSA at the airport.

FOOD - 4 stars...the sushi really rocks here, not top echelon but good for a quick bite
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...minimal and spacious
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...very attentive like we were important or something
TOTAL - 4 stars...sushi satisfaction in the heart of Hayes Valley
author: Ed U.

description: Excellent service, and the fish quality was superb. The sashimi really melts in your mouth. Best sushi I've had in the city.
author: Lawrence J.

description: Fish quality is a par with what you pay for. Very fresh and clean. Hard to get a table but worth the wait or make reservation. Personally recommend wild salmon nigiri and negi toro
author: Eugenia C.

description:
Poor unhygienic handling of fish. Fridge cooler always left open. Sushi came warm. 

Would have left if friend wasn't stubborn.
author: Amy L.

description: Came here last Saturday for dinner. I had a reservation and was seated promptly. The restaurant wasn't pack, but it filled up. Parking can be bad around this area. I went straight for the omakase 12 pieces for $80. They started off with 2 plates of 4 pieces of nigiri, then 3 pieces and 1 grand piece. Each pieces was exceptional seasoned and fresh. Two of my favorites was the butterfish and scallops. I normally do not even like or order those fish, but I loved it. I do wish the last piece, uni was bigger portion. In between the plates they had complimentary dishes, like a fried eggplant soaked with a sauce, the flavor was amazing and you couldn't even tell it was fried. The whole course did take about to 1.5 hrs like the menu noted. At the end the chef sent over waygu nigiri, it was amazinggggg. Overall the omakase experience and ambiance was great for the price.
author: Suzy Z.

description:
Do you know how limited my sushi options are out in this area? Especially when I've got a strict one hour time limit.

There's so much bad sushi in the world. We really ought to shut 'em all down because of the overfishing problem 



Say no to pseu-shi, but say yes to Tsubasa. 

I'm not a bento person and I don't eat rolls often. Tsubasa offers pretty damn good chirashi and sake-don for lunch. While the chirashi is almost too beautiful to eat (the presentation is gorgeous!) and offers a nice small variety of fish, my heart belongs to the sake-don. Love the ikura they throw in there.. What really does it for me at Tsubasa is the sushi rice. The shari is perfect!! Nice amount of vinegar (and I'm sure they use a dark one because there's a slight tint to the rice) and perfectly cooked. They're friendly and they remember me. I need to come back for dinner!
author: Susy C.

description:
I was super stoked for Tsubasa tonight. It was a special weekend, and I was meeting up with a high school friend for the first time in SF, so we were planning to do some sort of omakase somewhere. My friend organized, and apparently a bunch of those omakase places were pretty fully booked, but she was able to get reservations at Tsubasa, which also offered omakase, and at a more affordable price than some other places I came across when looking up restaurants. We knew we wanted to try some nigiri, but we were super indecisive, and asked the server to recommend some stuff, but of course we had no idea what our preferences were either so he recommended we get the Chef's Omakase. Good recommendation XD We also ordered a couple of appetizers as well.

- Chef's Omakase: we originally got the 8 piece, but upgraded to 12 piece at the end of dinner since we still had room to spare hehe. I've never had omakase before, and my family usually orders the same like 3 things at Japanese places (salmon maki, dynamite roll, and salmon sashimi lol), so I welcome any opportunity to try new things. And boy was the nigiri such a treat! I actually wrote down the names of all the nigiri haha. I really loved how each combination was served with such care with each of the flavours, and how the server directing us to eat in a certain direction kind of made sense. No soy sauce was needed either, since the nigiri was already marinated with special sauce. My friend made the soy sauce mistake, and the server told her soy sauce wasn't eneded haha. My favourite nigiri combination was the following:
    - Amberjack: citrus notes
    - Golden eye snapper: kind of the bridge
    - Butterfish: some hot sauce
    - It was cool how there was that contrast in the combination. I also liked how there were a few "bonus" kind of small dishes that came with the omakase, including an eggplant marinated in a light sauce, not too sweet or strong in any sense, and the eggplant absorbed a lot of the sauce, giving it more flavour.
    - Our last 4 pieces of omakase came in 2 rounds, with the fatty toro and gold leaf, and barracuda with a little piece of uni on top getting A+ on presentation
    - The real uni was a great way to end of the omakase, definitely a real treat. I've never actually had uni before! It was very smooth and had a rich but not overbearing flavour. 
    - I also enjoyed the few pieces of nigiri that were slightly torched on top. 

- Appetizer trio (I forgot the name): also recommended by our server. It came with 3 items (apologies for the non-official names, I don't remember what they were called haha)
    - Ankimo: monkfish liver. 5 years ago, I wouldn't touch any kind of liver, dead or alive, with a 10ft stick. But I guess tastes change, and I'm glad I'm more adventurous now. This was an interesting experience and it wasn't bad!
    - Tuna + white suff: well, the white stuff was super sticky and apparently it's made of yam! It reminded me of spit or something (ok maybe too graphic for dinner time talk XD), and I didn't quite enjoy this, maybe because of the consistency but also it tasted a bit funky. The server recommended to mix some soy sauce with it to lessen the stickiness, but I just avoided the yam and enjoyed the tuna by itself instead haha.
    - Ikura: I've actually had the big fish roe before! I've had plenty of the little fish eggs that come on sushi, but never ikura or that kind. It was very rich in flavour, and I loved the pop when it exploded in my mouth. Reminded me of the exploding boba hehe.

- Unagi Chawanmushi: I love chawanmushi, and it's not a super common thing at normal Japanese restaurants, so whenever this is offered I jump at the opportunity. The chawanmushi was probably the least stand out of the dishes tonight, as it may have been lacking that bit of something, but it was still good, and a nice piping hot bowl to (almost) end of the night.

- Dessert: green tea ice cream and mochi for the special occasion ;) I'm a sucker for green tea ice cream, and it was great. The mochi was ok, but I'm still glad we got to try it. Definitely a nice way to end such a delicious dinner. 

I can't believe all this beautifully presented and delicious nigiri in omakase is what I've been missing in my life! I wouldn't have my first omakase any other way, and I'd definitely recommend Tsubasa, especially for a more affordable omakase meal :)
author: Joanna C.

description:
Phenomenal Japanese restaurant located in the Hayes Valley district of SF. Came here with a friend for an early dinner on Friday. We both ordered the 12 piece nigiri omakase, and an unagi chawanmushi (separately) to share. Our meal consisted of the following courses:

1. Sesame tofu starter
2. 4 nigiris (flounder, char, snapper, amberjack)
3. 4 nigiris (scallop, chuutoro, flying fish, mackerel)
4. Complimentary piece of eggplant
5. 3 nigiris (wild cherry salmon, barracuda & uni, toro)
6. Unagi chawanmushi
7. Uni nigiri with ikura
8. Candied tomato dessert

All of the items were fantastic. Each piece of nigiri was unique and very fresh. My favorites were the wild cherry salmon and the toro. Both were extremely juicy -- the umami of the fish just burst in my mouth with every bite.

The service was very friendly - the waiters and waitresses carefully explained each item that came with our omakase meal. They also checked in very frequently with us to make sure we were ready for the next course.

Overall, this was a very memorable experience. The price came out to be $90 per person after taxes and tips, which I felt was perfect given the fantastic quality of the food and the friendly and efficient service at Tsubasa. Very highly recommended!
author: Alvin W.

description: Tried this restaurant for the first time for boyfriend's birthday  Omakase was well worth it. Service was wonderful!!!
author: Selina P.

description:
3.5 STARS

When I hear about a new sushi bar opening, my eyes light up and...my wallet cries of the impending damage. If you want to good stuff, you have to put out. Well, your wallet does.

I've been to The One Sushi & Lounge once and never again. It was the typical stereotypical Chinesey sushi place - bad fish and even worse service. Last month, The One Sushi & Lounge reincarnated into Tsusaba Sushi, supposedly with new owners. I read that they offer omakase and the pictures looked enticing enough to stop by for lunch. 

Upon walking in, I noticed some of the same staff as The One Sushi & Lounge but they now have a Japanese sushi chef. Unfortunately, omakase is not offered during lunch (different lunch and dinner menu). Disappointingly, there's only 4 nigiri options for lunch (sake, hamachi, binnaga maguro, and unagi) but there's lots of maki roll options, if that's your thing - traditional and fusion rolls. They also have bento boxes for about $13. Fish is sourced locally and from Japan. 

The nigiri was the highlight of my lunch. 

*Sake (2 pc - $6): http://bit.ly/1RBkjRW
*Hamachi (2 pc - $7): http://bit.ly/1RBki0o
*Otoro (2 pc - $13): http://bit.ly/1pK33hj

For Hayes Valley, the nigiri was solid and a huge improvement over its predecessor. The neta was l-o-n-g and beautifully cut. The sake and hamachi were uber fresh, silky, and buttery. I was having a bad day and felt like splurging so I asked the sushi chef if he had otoro available and he did. Maybe it was the cut but the otoro was firm and didn't have that melt-in-your-mouth quality it should have. This is more of a preference but the shari could have been used more vinegar, salt, and sugar since all nigiri comes seasoned sans wasabi (no need for soy sauce). 

As a filler, I also ordered the Mixed Tempura: Shrimp w/ rice cracker, eryngi mushroom, zucchini, asparagus ($7): http://bit.ly/1RzDEwK. Unless you like hard, greasy batter, I would skip this. The shrimp was definitely frozen as it was wet in the center. 

I made the mistake of ordering a maki roll from their fusion section instead of the traditional section (there's another sushi chef in charge of making the rolls). I appreciated that they were light on the rice for the Juicy Scallop Roll ($13): http://bit.ly/1o8TNkY but the roll was no bueno. The scallops had a slight slimy texture and the sour miso sauce looked like man chowdah. The sweet and sourness of the sauce was overwhelming and was a funky pairing for raw seafood. 

The female server was really polite and attentive. I was one of two diners during a late lunch so I enjoyed the peacefulness. 

I know having their entire omakase selection available for lunch is impossible but I would love to see more nigiri options during lunch. Granted, an all nigiri lunch will be $$$$ so it's a good thing I have an office stash of $1 Nongshim ramen bowls from Walgreens!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night and decided to order the omakase, because WHY NOT? It was around 8pm and  quiet - you probably don't need to make reservations later in the evening, though we did. 

There are several different omakase options - we went for the more expensive, 15-piece ($75) nigiri omakase and it was SO worth it. We also ordered the appetizer sampler trio, which was unnecessary in the end because we were way too full. We sat at the bar for a more intimate experience (you can watch the chef lovingly make eace piece, which sometimes involves paintbrushes, blowtorches, and gold leaf!).

Some favorites from the night:
- Wagyu nigiri. OH MY GOD. This is the A5 stuff, aka the best wagyu beef out there - google it and it looks like lace from the marbling. Melted in our mouths. If nothing else, this makes it worth it to get the 15-piece omakase because I'm not sure it is included in the 12-piece one.
- Mugi hotate (scallop) nigiri with yuzu-infused flying fish roe. Tsubasa's head chef, Peter, has designed this absurdly delicious citrusy yuzu sauce that made an appearance in several pieces. It is unlike any flavor I've had with nigiri, and really brings out the brightness of clean, fresh fish.
- Chu-toro (fatty tuna belly) nigiri. While not as melt-in-your-mouth rich as toro, the chi-toro was flavorful, fresh, and almost creamy in texture. And let's be honest, the gold leaf makes you feel #fancy.
- The additions (not included in the 15 pieces): Oysters, miso soup with fish filets, dash-soaked eggplant (looks odd but is a flavor-bomb of dash goodness), and candied tomatoes for dessert. All filling, hearty, and yummy!

Food: 5/5 - Absurdly good food, decadent flavors, and so much variety. Plus the attention to detail was unparalleled - the delicate yes sauces, the house-made soy sauce blends - every detail was on point, the way you'd expect in a much more expensive restaurant.

Drinks: 4/5 - We had the (FILL IN) sake, which was delicious, but pricey. Pro tip - offer some sake to your sushi chef! It is traditional, and always appreciated :)

Service: 5/5 - our server John was friendly, knowledgeable, and fun without seeming like he was trying to hard. The banter between the chefs was hilarious - you can tell these guys are friends in addition to coworkers. The chefs and hosts are really authentic and approachable while still being professional. John gave detailed descriptions of all the food that we had, and answered all of our questions in detail. As major food nerds, this made for an incredible experience. Food came out quickly but not in a way that made us feel rushed.

Value: 4/5 - at $75 for 15 incredible pieces (some of which - like the wagyu - ran over $10/piece a la carte), this was an incredible deal. Throw various small bites on top of that, and you have yourself an incredibly filling, decadent meal at an unheard of price - especially in SF! Of course, with tip the bill still came to ~275 for two people, so this isn't exactly a cheap place. Would recommend for a fancy date night

Ambience: 3/5 - I wouldn't say the ambience was particularly memorable. The food is the focus here.
author: L H.

description: The search for top notch sushi in sf continues.  Prices are pretty decent for sf but having just come back from Tokyo maybe my standards increased a little bit and Tsubasa is just my first review that doesn't compare.  Tried the chu toro and it didn't have the same taste as what I had in Tokyo.  Hamachi and other sushi just so so.  Sorry.
author: V N.

description:
Came here on a first date and it was really nice. The atmosphere and service is really great for a first date. Quiet enough to talk but busy enough that there's things you can talk about in the restaurant.

Food was solid. Nothing wow-ing but delicious overall.
author: Mimi T.

description: The quality of fish was great, but I can find the same quality elsewhere for a better price. It's $27 for 4 pieces of nigiri (for the chef's sampler). I also had a piece of bone in my fish, which has never happened to me before!
author: J. A.

description: Fantastic quality of Sushi. They don't answer the phone. Be there at opening time if you have a theater to go to. Otherwise after 8:00pm
author: David F.

description: Food always excellent.... staff charming and attentive. Tempura has light breading and a favorite. Spider roll also s go to item. Great place before opera , ballet or symphony....,
author: J. Robert M.

description:
My boyfriend took me here on New Year's Eve and we fell in love! The place is small but the service and food were just the best combination! We came earlier than our reservation but they were able to accommodate us immediately. We checked in often to see how we were doing and cleared our plates instantly. Food came out a bit slow but there was only two chefs serving food for omakase style. It's a bit pricey but it's so worth it.

12pcs omakase for $60. The spanish mackerel is to die for! That was my favorite besides the uni and toro. All the pieces just melted in my mouth! The uni came out last and came with salmon roe (marinated in their homemade soy sauce). It was a bit salted eating it alone but when eaten with the rice and uni, it was just heaven!

Oshizushi - pressed sushi with toro. We were going to get the toro handroll but the waiter suggested the pressed sushi instead. I always wanted to try pressed sushi (it's a few dollars more) but it did not disappoint. We loved it! It was a bit a rice but the rice was seasoned and had sesame seeds - it was just delicious! I could eat just the rice alone!

Green tea ice cream with homemade mochi - can't leave without dessert. Words cannot describe! You could definitely tell it's green tea ice cream and their homemade mochi was so soft and chewy. A bit bland but that's how mochi is. Mix it with eh green tea ice cream and it's a great combo!

They gave us candied tomatoes at the very end of the meal. It was interesting but I probably wouldn't eat it again haha. It was not bad nor good but it is something you should try once in your life.

I will definitely came back here. I love the food and service. Great way to end the year of 2016 with - a perfect meal!
author: Linda N.

description: Saw 4.5 stars review came with some expectations. bit disappointed. Services were excellent but food was not great . We did order the Omakase, rice was hard tasted like leftover rice. Prepping was not great, i can tell it was cut properly, uni was not fresh. I had eat better one.  It costes about $70, not worth. We ordered a bottle sake, but it was pour in a container so we didn't even know did we get cheated. I wouls rather pay a little bit more to have better Omakase.
author: Lori T.

description: This is the best sushi I have ever had. I've been to Michelin star sushi places, but hands down Tsubasa is the best. Such a decent price and incredible quality fish. Thank you so much Tsubasa for coming to the Bay Area and gracing us with your delicious food.
author: Thea B.

description:
For the price of their omakase, this place is definitely worth a try! Looks like they've just increased their omakase price to $68 for 12pcs of sushi instead of $60. You get an appetizer at the beginning and another amuse bouche in between the sushi courses. The 12 pcs sushi is divided into 5 different servings. 
1st plate:
- sea robin
- rudy snapper 
- artic char
2nd plate:
- star butterfish
- baby yellowtail
- spanish mackerel
3rd plate:
- wild butterfish
- chu toro
- fresh scallops
4th plate:
- barracuda
- toro
5th plate:
- uni

We love most of the sushi, a few taste a bit "fishy", but overall it's a great meal!

Parking is tough in this area, we took uber since it's easier. Reservation is pretty easy to make online.
author: Prisilia P.

description: This place is awesome!  Great sushi, great sake.  What's not to like.  Order exclusively off the special menu.  They get fresh fish flown in from Japan.  Amazing!
author: John B.

description: One of the best sushi spots in San Francisco- Tsubasa sushi!!! Ordered the omakase 8 pc with uni and Ikura combination. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable and catered to us.
author: Denise F.

description:
Tsubasa is the best sushi experience in SF. At first glance, It doesn't attempt to impress with fancy decor or with an overly complicated menu. Instead the story that you get from Tsubasa is a mom and pop shop nestled in the heart of Hayes valley that has really elevated its game. Once you try their nigiri sushi, you'll know what I mean. We started off by ordering the 12 piece nigiri omakase. The fishes we particularly enjoyed include the wild caught mackerel, wild caught yellow tail, the blue shrimp, king salmon, butterfish and of course the Toro was immaculate. 

5 stars, I strongly recommended dining here.
author: Eugene S.

description: One of my go to sushi spots for no frills high-quality sushi. They have a nice long list of nigiri / sashimi options with lots of specialty fish you won't see on other menus. Pretty easy to get a reservation, too.
author: Julie N.

description:
It was a random Saturday visit, but I'm so happy about it. I think one of the best places with Japanese cuisine. Small restaurant, but nice. Smell of wood in the air adds some kind of peace to your mind and you can enjoy your food. My meal was like a small art show. Fresh complementary starter, delicious sashimi and unexpected taste of Uni in the end. 
I will absolutely come there one day.
author: Barbara K.

description: This was a good Omakase value ($68) and the fish was very fresh.  I also ordered the unagi chawanmushi, the Atlantic crab and unagi nigiri.  Everything was really good and the meal was well paced. Service was good and the location is trendy.
author: Andrew S.

description: Great quality sushi with amazing service. They give great sake recommendations, as it's admittedly something I know nothing about. This is my go to sushi spot in Hayes Valley!
author: Abby E.

description: You can tell an authentic Japanese restaurant by Miao soup and sashimi . Love love love this restaurant! Pretty decent and authentic like the one I had in Japan. Price is reasonable and sashimi is *fresh* ! Just become my favorite Japanese restaurant in SF
author: Jiani S.

description:
After finishing our shopping on Hayes St at 7pm on a Saturday (when it seems that all the shops tend to close in this area), we were fortunate to walk in and land an available table at Tsubasa Sushi which had quite a number of tables reserved and all the sushi bar area filled up. At sushi restaurants, I tend to gravitate toward the omakase while the wife prefers a couple of rolls with a side of uni if available & the diverse options by Tsubasa suited our preferences well. I had a wonderful 8 piece nigiri omakasa which included mackerel, flounder, fatty tuna, perch, a huge piece of scallop, and arctic char. The S.T.A.S.H. roll was very impressive with large pieces of seared yellowtail and seared just enough without overdoing it. Inside the S.T.A.S.H. roll were asparagus and spicy tuna which made a really interesting mix of flavors in this roll.  I think I would come back and just order like two or three S.T.A.S.H. rolls. The Futomaki roll was good but just a step below the S.T.A.S.H. roll and had more of a vegetarian flair with the egg, mushroom, pickled radish, asparagus, and wrapped in Japanese kelp. Eel was also in the roll as well.  The uni was a solid 8 out of 10.

Throughout the meal, waiters brought out other complimentary items including a pumpkin tofu,  fried eggplant in a sweet broth, and yam cake for dessert. The yam cake came soaked in a sweet syrup and was just amazing. The pumpkin tofu was very creative, likely a seasonal item, and very light in flavor in that you couldn't really taste the pumpkin that much but it was a great way to start off the dinner. Our server indicated before the holidays started, they had offered an edamame tofu. Tsubasa Sushi just took honors for our favorite sushi restaurant in the Bay Area and we'll certainly find ourselves coming back here again hopefully in the near future. You can't seem to go wrong if you get only the omakase or a bunch of rolls accompanied with cold/hot appetizers.
author: Albie F.

description: My favorite place in the city for sushi hands down! Always fresh and delicious sushi, friendly and amazing service!
author: Olga T.

description: I'm a regular here. It's my default for sushi when I'm not trying something new. They have a fresh menu every day, and serve the classics plus all kinds of fish you don't see elsewhere in town. Like "Wild BoneMouth," "Blackthroat Sea Perch," "Goat Fish," and "Amberstripe Scad," which are on the menu tonight. They do it well, too, and usually end with a cute free dessert. Everything is delicious and you should go here if your interest is good sushi.
author: Craig H.

description: So close to my apt. Dangerously close. Waited much too long for our table bc the chefs were overwhelmed by the omakase orders that night. We eventually got seated, after I almost fainted from starvation. I'm kidding but we had killed some time getting drinks around the corner down the street and after 1.5 waiting and the host couldn't seat us. We suggested we'll just munch on edamames first. For the long wait the host was kind enough to give us a bottle of sake on the house. The sushi was surprisingly fresh. Everything was delicious and I'll certainly go back again!
author: Sandy P.

description: My boyfriend made a reservation here on a Saturday for my early birthday dinner. It was amazing! The wait staff were all so nice and attentive! We ordered the special sashimi and the waitress took the time to explain what everything was and how to eat it. It was so pretty and delicious, but definitely not enough food for two people. We also ordered the STASH roll, king salmon nigiri, smoked barracuda nigiri, and the snow crab nigiri. The snow crab was so good, we ordered a second round. Overall, I highly recommend this place! Great food, staff, and ambiance.
author: Debo R.

description: Everything I could have asked for in a sushi restaurant. Price was moderately expensive but the selection of hard to find fish was exceptional! Definitely get a reservation because it's a small restaurant. We discovered this place 2 months ago and made the trip into the city 4 more times in the same month. Almost resisted posting a positive review to try and keep this place from getting more difficult to get seating :)
author: Daniel J.

description: Excellence selection of fresh sushi. I tried firefly squid, scorpion fish, tuna and many others. Every bite was heavenly. Helpful and friendly staff was able offer suggestions based on our pallets and preferences. Impeccably clean.
author: Ryu B.

description: A rising star - young sushi chefs of Hayes Valley. Creative new dishes and a selection of unusual and rare sushi. Recently 2017 Michelin Recommended! The crab chawanmushi egg custard is really good and flavorful. Wild cherry salmon, wild japanese yellow jack, onagadai kobujime ruby snapper marinated in kelp. Highly recommend the sesame paste asparagus, delicious. Reservation highly recommended. Early hour walk-ins welcome but time is limited
author: Dilys S.

description:
I really wish I could give half points, because this is a solid 3.5. I wouldn't travel across the city for it but if you're looking for a nigiri evening without four dollar signs this is a good option. Our order:

Toro Nigiri - I felt that this was actually a chu toro cut. It was reasonably-ish priced, but for $7 a piece I want otoro, not chu toro. It was good enough, not best ever.

Miso Soup - Kind of watery, will skip next time.

Juicy Scallop Roll - This was the best sushi entree and I wish we ordered two. It's really balanced and fresh. I think it can be difficult to take a minimalist approach to a sushi roll and make it sing and they have done that here.

Mixed Tempura - delicious. It was basically all asparagus, porcini mushroom, and 1 shrimp rolled in Japanese crackers.

King Salmon Nigiri - I thought this was kind of fishy. I feel like maybe they cured or smoked or 
both (or otherwise dehydrated) the fish because the texture was lox-y but it wasn't blowing my mind. A friend we ate with thought it was incredible but next time I'd pass.

S.T.A.S.H. Roll - Would pass on this. Each element was good but not together. The roll is covered with torched yellowtail and they overdid the searing to the point that it was overcooked. The spicy tuna roll underneath with asparagus felt out of place and I'm not sure the asparagus did the spicy tuna any favors. All in all a very lackluster preparation to which I would definitely say PASS.

Oshizushi (boxed sushi) - I thought this was pretty good and would gladly order again. Bluefin tuna on quality rice lightly torched, what can go wrong?

--

Our total for dinner for a party of 3 (including drinks) came to $125 pre-tip, which was super reasonable for what it was. Don't know if anyone on Yelp gives a shit but none of the waiters I experienced spoke Japanese, however I'm sure it's Japanese owned with a name like Tsubasa.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Sushi purists rejoice. The omakase at Tsubasa is one of the best deals in SF! 8 pieces of nigiri for $40 or 12 pieces for $60 is unheard of in this town, especially when the quality of the fish is on par with that of Akiko's or Omakase, imho. 

I ordered the 12 pc omakase and it came with super fresh and seasonal fish like amberjack, horse mackerel, giant clam and fatty tuna. The rice was well seasoned and served at just the right temperature (hallmark of good sushi). I also really enjoyed the small dishes (edamame tofu, ankimo, braised eggplant) in between the sushi. This meal would have easily cost twice as much somewhere else! 

The staff and chefs are friendly and knowledgeable.  If you are a sushi lover like me, you must check out this new Hayes Valley gem before the word gets out.
author: Alice W.

description:
I ended up here while looking for a place to have dinner before attending a show at the San Francisco Opera house. 

They kindly and gracefully accepted my party of two without a reservation, and I am happy they did because the food is excellent, the service great, and the sake selection very good. 

I recommend this place wholeheartedly, and hope to come back one of these days when I am in San Francisco again.
author: Pablo R.

description: Booked a reservation here for dinner with a friend of mine for her birthday and I'm so happy I did! I just found it randomly looking through Yelp and I was like "I'll check it out"! So so good! $68 for their 12 course omakase dinner and it was out of this world! Every single piece of fish was fresh and extent flavorful. Couldn't be happier! I'm a legit yelp/real person talking about this place! Go here!
author: Tham H.

description:
Came here with a friend and they asked us to sit at the bar area while they prepared our seats...Which was off since the place was half full and they had seated us at the sushi bar where it didn't look like they had someone there before...The quality was pretty decent and not sure it matched the price we paid. We had both ordered the Omakase because what else is there to order here. It's good that there was an option to add extras but couldn't really order anything a la carte. 

They told us what came out when they severed it but most didn't match what we saw on the menu so that threw us off a bit. We kept trying g to keep track of what we had and what else was remaining but still couldn't figure it out. They did stay on top of service and kept giving us hot water for our tea, which was great since it was so cold outside!
author: Richard L.

description:
Wonderful sushi spot in Hayes Valley! Recommended by a coworker for a casual Wednesday outing and we had a great time. 

The staff is very warm and welcoming, even brought us a complimentary appetizer to try. The decor and ambiance is awesome, right in the cute little area of Hayes Valley (which is the coolest part of town to hang out now, very chic spots). We had a bunch of sashimi and custard egg things, which were yummy! 

It got a bit crowded 7pm and after with a good lively crowd, obviously enjoying some sake and shooters. We had reserved a table by the window, so might want to do that just for back up.

Definitely would be back with a small group! Thanks guys!
author: Mahsa T.

description:
I would definitely recommend going here for lunch, but not for dinner unless you are JUST craving sushi.

For lunch, they have other items than sushi and they have a solid bento box. For dinner, they only have sushi so if you are craving anything else you are out of luck!

I would definitely recommend their rainbow roll and their salmon and avocado roll. The sushi is really fresh and you can tell they care a lot about the presentation of the food.

Parking is somewhat hard to find out in Hayes but if you're willing to walk you'll be able to find a spot. 

Overall, this place has solid sushi and for a reasonable price.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Such a fantastic experience! My partner and I came here around 5:30 -  6:00 pm on a Sunday and were seated right away. We ordered a couple different chef's recommended nigiri and everything was super tasty and exceeded our expectation. The chef's recommended scallop was buttery and just melted in our mouths. The unicorn leatherjacket fish was extremely memorable, as were the regular hamachi and chef's recommended ebi. Service was extremely nice. We sat at the bar and the chef made sure that we were happy with the food we got every time he served us a dish. They also gave us two complimentary oysters and two complimentary desserts in the mean time. We are very satisfied with our experience and would definitely come here again.
author: Catherine T.

description: Stumbled upon this because Domo was closed. Didn't think we'd uncover this gem of a sushi place! Superb quality and totally worth the money. Great service too!
author: Felicia C.

description: First thing I noticed was the smell. The place smelled of old fish which a Sushi place should never smell like Sushi was ok and service was fine. I wasn't that impressed. Shiitake roll was disappointing.  Instead of putting a sauteed mushroom they brined it in soy sauce.  The spicy tuna tasted like spicy canned tuna not sure why.  Rainbow roll was ok.
author: Adriana B.

description:
UPDATE: I came back today to make sure I wasn't dreaming...everything was just as goid if not better than last night. We had a few different items like clam today. Extremely tender and delicately scrumptious! We also tried dessert tonight. Green tea ice cream with fresh housemade mochi. Mochi was so tender and soft, and I loved those tiny toasted rice "sprinkles" that garnished the dessert. 

So sad I don't live closer to this place... The fish is so FRESH and all the fish is so delish!!! At first we ordered the 8-piece omakase but after the first 4 pieces of nigiri I had to up my order to the 12-piece. Everything was so fresh and delicious. For piece #12 piece de resistence, I had the uni with fish eggs and my daughter had the toro with gold flake. So beautiful and tasty. Fish to rice nigiri ratio is perfect... Lots of fish, rice not overwhelming.

Service is exceptional. Food is excellent. Extremely fresh.  Prices very reasonable! This place is better than other places we've been to in LA.
author: Edie U.

description:
Tried this new spot on this long weekend, I and my partner really had a great time having lunch here. 

In the beginning we felt a little bit disappointed when getting the lunch menu lack of nigiri choices. We asked our server if there was some fish not on the menu we can order. After he checked with the chef and kitchen, he brought us a dinner menu and told us there might be some fish available. We're glad this restaurant was able to accommodate our need.

Back to the food itself, we ordered 8 kinds of nigiri and all of them were delicious. The chefs know their fish very well and are good at dealing with them.
We also ordered ankimo, mixed tempura, and toro hand roll, all were tasty. I'll definitely come back for omakase dinner!
author: Chen-ling L.

description: I walk from Japantown to the Mission at least once or twice a week. I was in the mood for Sushi, and had passed this place often, and decided to stop for lunch. It was a busy lunch time and the place filled up quickly. But service was quick, efficient and friendly. I ordered edamame for an appetizer and the Salmon Bowl for lunch. It was all delivered quickly and it was not only visually appealing, but very fresh and delicious. I'll be going back again to sample other great menu items..
author: Timothy L.

description:
We ordered the 12 piece omakase after reading previous reviews, and were really impressed! The fish was high quality and perfectly seasoned (no additional soy sauce necessary). It was a good opportunity to try nigiri I wouldn't normally order on my own. The only thing I would say is that the timing is a bit rushed - initially, each piece was brought out after the previous had been eaten, and the waiter even took the time to mark down each piece on our menu; but towards the latter half of the meal pieces of nigiri came out served by other waiters before the previous had even been touched. Here's what we were served:

1) wild spotted perch
2) arctic char
3) flounder marinated in kelp
4) amberjack
5) wild golden eye snapper
6) wild horse mackerel
7) chu-toro (medium fatty tuna belly)
8) scallop
9) yellowjack
10) wild barracuda
11) toro (fatty tuna belly)
12) uni

Overall, at $68 it isn't a cheap meal but worth it for the omakase experience. Will definitely return.
author: Shannon F.

description: I was looking for a good dinner spot near the War Memorial and the affordable omakase caught my attention. The 12 pieces of fish was excellent quality and the last dish, sea urchin nigiri with salmon roe, was a big highlight. Service was attentive... even slowing down the pace of the omakase when we started taking our time. Even if you're stuffed by the end, the Oshizushi shouldn't be missed.
author: Samantha L.

description: Great food and service. But some of the sushi wasn't as fresh as I'd hope for. I think for the prices there could be more creativity with the a la cart menu as well.
author: F S.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding up. If you're like me, "$60 omakase" is what your caught eye. An omakase in the city usually starts at $100, so it's refreshing to find a quality spot that won't break the bank. Just know that you will likely spend more to get full.

My girlfriends and I came for dinner and ordered the 15-piece sashimi and 12-piece nigiri omakases (both $60). We also split a few appetizers as well as complimentary dishes. The sashimi is all brought out at once while the nigiri is staggered with 3-4 pieces brought out at a time. Everyone in my group was really happy with our food but we were also tipsy, and that may have heightened the experience.

The fish quality and variety was good. I wasn't disappointed there. They gave us king salmon, scallop, mackerel, and more. A generous slab of uni was the grand finale and it was amazing.

The size of the nigiri could have been bigger, hence the lower rating. I'm positive the nigiri was smaller relative to other places. While my other friend said she felt full, I could have kept going.

Next time around, I'll try a smaller omakase and supplement with a few other dishes.

This is a perfectly good place to get your omakase fix at a decent price point, but don't expect the most over-the-top, fantastic dining experience.
author: Valerie L.

description:
I ordered the 12 piece sushi omakase, the chawanmushi and the zensai sanshu. The zensai sanshu was a nice sampler, and the chawanmushi was satisfying and creamy. The omakase, however, did not meet my expectations. The nigiri came with very generous amounts of fish, but I personally thought that the pieces were too big and were very tiring to eat. The quality of the fish was great, but nothing too special. If you appreciate a larger proportion of fish to rice, you will probably like Tsubasa Sushi. However, I thought this was far too much fish for my taste and made the whole meal seem monotonous.

The sushi portion of the omakase came with four pieces of sushi at once instead of the traditional piece by piece style. Service was average as the waiters unnecessarily brought more dishes of sushi to us even when we weren't finished with the first dishes of the omakase.

I don't feel too compelled to come back, but I still think it's worth a try for those who like very large pieces of fish on their sushi.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Came here for dinner and the food was good, great services, very good sushi chefs checking make sure your dishes are good. The environment was pretty chill. 

I recommend this place if your near by.
author: Christina H.

description:
----update 6-2017-----
Wasn't able to get in without a reservation last time we came by. In 5 years this hasn't ever happened. Wasn't really invited to put our name down to wait for a table. I didn't realize they'd gone to strict online reservations only. :/ 
------

Been coming here for a while and I love the new chef and menu! 

Prices are still reasonable. My favorite Hayes Valley spot!
author: Maryanne R.

description: Good atmosphere and very attentive service. I was mildly adventurous in my nigiri selection, after a helpful conversation with the server, and the results were quite good but somewhat meagre. Knowing that a full meal of nigiri would be an expensive proposition, we also had some basic maki, which were nothing special, but good and fresh. Grilled yellowtail collar came out last, and for me that was the best part of the meal, especially as it was well garnished with a variety of pretty intense seaweed. I'd go back but I'd probably order a fusion roll or two instead of the maki.
author: Steve C.

description:
Update: the chefs changed :( it's not as good anymore.

I live close by and needed to find a lunch place for my bf's sister, I was actually thinking of Domo, but then this place showed up with better review so I went there.

This sushi place is the best I have found so far for chirashi and nigiri in SF. The fish was yummy and the rice was flavored really nicely. I love the food here. It is by far the best sushi I had in San Francisco!! 

Note: this place used to host a subpar sushi place but the menu and food is 100% different now. 

Note 2: We also had some tempura - I don't recommend getting it (nothing special and not fried that well) unless you really don't like fish.

Note 3: if you are on a budget come here for lunch. They serve the same lunch menu on Sat.

Update note: I am still a regular. Their sushi is still top notch. Guys, I am still seeing everyone eat rolls here: my question to all of you is: why?! Their Sashimi and Nigiri is what really excel here since their fish is very good... you can taste the difference much better when you get the fish outside of rolls.
author: Clara Y.

description: We came here on Wednesday night and pleasantly seated upon our arrival. We didn't have to wait maybe because of the weekday? boyfriend and I ordered Sashimi omakase and we absolutely loved the quality and variety of the fish selection! Japanese uni was the perhaps the best I tried in the city. Waitstaff were friendly and knowledgeable! I'd recommend the sashimi omakase and albacore tataki.
author: Joon G.

description:
My boyfriend and I had dinner for the first time at Tsubasa on September 29th and again to celebrate my boyfriend's 40th birthday on November 17th. Sushi Chef - John does not disappoint. His skills are on point and presentation is displayed with great love and appreciation for detail. The price is perfect for really good sushi in the city. We did the Omakase style sushi and served us a variety of silky, buttery, fatty types of fish. Overall we had a wonderful experience for the 2nd time and we will be coming here again next year! From the hostess, to the servers, to the sushi chefs at the bar they are all very engaging and pleasant. 

To the comments from others who will not come back because they have seen the chefs not wash their hands, I would ask them so what happens to the restaurants they go to and their kitchen is not visible? Or the other comment about their sushi chef not being interactive, did you ever ask yourself that maybe it was you who wasn't asking engaging questions, being personable were it would allow the sushi chef to open up in conversation.
author: Danielle L.

description: This place is amazing. True hidden gym in Hayes Valley. Had some drunk couple come in complaining about something ridiculous. Everyone around us had a great time. But other than that. Great service and even better head Chef. Make sure you come check out head chef Peter. Amazing sushi place in the City with great service.  Need more of these.
author: Jason H.

description:
One of the best sushi place in the city. I love everything about this place. :) 

Fantastic Food 
Excellent service 
Clean
- $60 omakase for 12pcs -fresh n premium fish
- buttery toro n salmon 

I can't remember the names but just show them the picture. 
Will definitely be coming back! 
See you soon fishessssss!!
author: Sophia V.

description:
I'm currently still sitting at the bar and I can't stop raving about this place to my friends through text as I inhale every morsel of each delectable nigiri. 

With the three nirigi omakase options of 4 piece at $18, 8 pieces at $36, 12 pieces at $54, I wanted to try the 8 pieces with the mindset of ordering other items on the menu. 

Luckily, I saved room to try the Zensai Sanchu appetizer which included ankimo, ikura oroshi, and toro-toro. Translation for the aforementioned includes fish liver, fish eggs, and fish belly. All served on a spoon with a hint of ponzu sauce. Each were sensational on its own. 

With the 8 piece nigiri which is seasoned by the chef, high level summary on how ecstatic I am about the next selection personally handed over by the chef.

I can't say more with how excited I am to find this gem without having to travel all the way out to the sunset for my beloved sushi go-to spot, Daigo.  Sayonara and konnichiwa!
author: Becky Q.

description: Decent but extremely small nigiri. Spent 150 and decided to get a cheeseburger instead. Not sure if this is a San Fran thing. In la I feel like I am getting some value even if I spend 150 a head I walk out full.
author: Scott K.

description:
Absolutely phenomenal meal tonight. Chef's choice of 12 pcs nigiri. Best Japanese meal I have had in years. Even the Uni was excellent!!!

Highly recommended. 

Highlights included the various mackerel selections; the king salmon and the butterfish. Also of special note was the "candied tomato" - a French inspired treatment with a Japanese perspective. 

Yum!!
author: Brett A.

description:
This may be my new favorite sushi spot in San Francisco, especially for nigiri - probably the best I've had in a long time (since Tokyo), and especially at reasonable prices. My other favorites are Saru Sushi (comparable prices but lengthier waits), and I've had good nigiri at Pink Zebra and Maruya, but at much steeper prices.

If you come here, make sure you order the nigiri. We ordered the 12 piece sampler of nigiri ($54) and the scallop roll, and it was enough food. The nigiri was all omakase, so chef's choice, and there were so many different types of textures, varieties of fish that I hadn't had before - not just your typical salmon, tuna, and hamachi), and prepared perfectly. The proportion of rice to fish was excellent (small pieces of rice with a large cut of fish), and different fish had different sauces brushed on them. Similar to how they prepare nigiri in Japan, some of the fish were charred or lightly seared, some had a particular sauce or topping that balanced each variety of fish perfectly, and none were eaten with wasabi or soy sauce. This is the way nigiri should be.

The scallop roll was also really good, with a miso sauce on top, but the standouts for me were the nigiri. We came late on a Friday night, so there was no wait, and I'm looking forward to making this my regular sushi place in San Francisco any time I want good nigiri. They seem to rotate the fish on a daily basis, depending on what's fresh. At around $40-50 per person, this is a pretty reasonable price for quality sushi, nigiri and sashimi.
author: Christina L.

description: Very good fish and rice, nigiri was excellent.  Convenient location, good sake selection and excellent service!
author: Glenn S.

description: Went a couple times, unlikely to go back unless I find myself on that block with no other options.
author: H S.

description: Our favorite local sushi spot! Staff is really friendly and the food is awesome. The chefs take so much care with each item on the  menu, it's a total treat for me and my husband when we get to go out for a date night. Make sure to get a reservation though, they book up fast and early.
author: Eurie K.

description:
Grew up in Japan, finding an authentic Japanese restaurant (especially Sushi restaurants) are my passion and KODAWARI (Super particular) after moving to SF. 

Pro: 
Reasonable Omakase price: Omakase Sushi 4 pc - $20, 8 piece - $40, 12pc - $60
Good Sake list with many common sakes and reasonably priced
Easy to book 
Hokkaido Scallop - order without Wasabi, taste the sweetness of Hokkaido :) 

Con: 
No bar seat experience: we were seated next to the roll guy, by looking, i think he is the newest and youngest apprentice. not much conversation... 
Uni: on the menu it says from Japan, but when i saw the box, it said "from Russia" (in Japanese).. when i asked the chef, i guess he doesn't speak Japanese so he asked the owner? and just told us yes it is from Russia...that is it, no sorry miss-print, nothing. now i wonder if other fish we ordered were actually from Japan. 
Wasabi: i am not one of those telling chef to remove the wasabi, but the chef put too much wasabi, it overtaken the flavor of the fish. In order to enjoy the sweetness of Hokkaido Scallop, i had to get another order of no wasabi - finally it was so good! 

the main chef (owner?) used to train with Ken-san from Yuzuki who trained with Sam's in San Mateo which is my go-to place. would i go back? probably not but i think the NETA (fish) was fresh and good enough for many people.
author: Sisi W.

description: Hand down best sushi experience I've had in SF - in my opinion. We sat at the sushi bar (I highly recommend doing so) and had the pleasure of ordering from Chef Peter who provided us with amazing service the entire night. The quality of the sushi was more than impressive and Chef Peter had the best recommendations. If you are in the Hayes Valley area come to Tsubasa - you won't regret it!!!
author: Heather A.

description: Had a craving for sushi and saw this place and took a chance. Wonderfully attentive and friendly service. Good sushi with interesting pieces for a set sushi lunch. Good choice for sushi if you are I. The neighborhood.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Tsubasa was on my bookmark page for a while and I finally got to try this place a couple weeks ago. Reservations was also very easy to make on Yelp. So, we got the 12 piece nigiri Omakase and all the pieces were amazing. The fishes were all very fresh, served at the perfect temperature, not too cold. All the sauces and decor paired with the fish were also very delicious. Loved the variety of fishes and other seafoods. Chef Peter was also very knowledgeable and dedicated to his craft. We even ordered 4 or 5 more nigiri cause 12 was just not enough. First time here and definitely won't be the last.
author: Julie N.

description:
Best sushi since moving to the Bay Area so far!

Food: 

Tsubasa's sushi is very fresh and generously cut. You can really taste the thought that goes into each piece of nigiri! 
The nigiri is prepared in a way that does not require additional seasoning, so the food just melts in your mouth. I really enjoyed each dish I ordered, and was delighted by each of the sushi's tastes. We ordered: fatty tuna, king salmon belly, uni, butterfish, live scallops, salmon & mackerel

Service:

Wait staff was attentive, and very helpful with recommending a sake that paired well with our meal. They also took the time out to explain each dish as they served it to us! I really enjoyed how the chefs sent out the sushi in small sets so that we could savor each piece one by one and space out our meal without being too stuffed at the end. The chefs were kind enough to give us complimentary dishes (a seaweed with octopus starter & saltwater eel nigiri). Probably because we had such obvious food-gasms ;-)

Price:

Very reasonable prices, especially for the quality and freshness of the fish. We ordered 8 different sets of nigiri with a bottle of sake and the total turned out to be $114!! 

Atmosphere:

-Clean and stylishly designed
-Nice music that wasn't distracting 
-Great view of the chefs!

Overall awesome experience, and I will be coming here again!
author: Brittani C.

description: We luckily got in for dinner without a reservation. This place fills up quick! The sushi was probably some of the best quality I've ever had.
author: Ryan S.

description:
I really like this place! The fish was really fresh and the prices were very reasonable. Spent $250 for three people and we were super stuffed. The staff was very attentive, and they gave us a lot of complimentary things like tofu and dessert. Also, if you come for a birthday, they give you free green tea ice cream and homemade mochi!! So yummy.

Some of my favorites:

- steamed egg with mushroom/crab
- Kamasu nigiri
- Kinmedai 
- King Salmon
-Toro
-Ankimo

Would recommend!
author: Mily W.

description: sushi is pretty good and has an extensive drink menu to boot. had a selection of nigiris and appetizers. it was all tasty but I've had better sushi in SF (Ijji, Maruya, Saru..). The ambiance is a bit impersonal and uninteresting - all the aforementioned places or Elephant or Tsunami have better ambiance. It's a solid 4.
author: Ruben K.

description:
Tsubasa Sushi is a cute little restaurant in the middle of Hayes Valley. We were forced to change plans when we found that Brenda's only serves breakfast for dinner on Sundays.

We ordered a bottle of Chardonnay, the mixed tempura, miso soups, seaweed salad, a S.T.A.S.H. roll, a T.A.P.S. roll and Tekka Maki. The mixed tempura was very unique, serving up corn, asparagus, and shrimp, rather than your standard green bean, onion ring, and potato. The seaweed salad was your standard prepackaged salad that every sushi restaurant serves (love it). The miso was pretty average, but all of the rolls were well rolled using high quality ingredients. The seared yellowtail on the S.T.A.S.H. roll paired well with the spicy tuna and the tempura gave a delightful crunch to the T.A.P.S. roll.

I generally order the same thing at every sushi restaurant (bento/dinner combination with tempura, sashimi, and sushi) and Tsubasa's small menu made me dance outside of this zone, but it's always a great sign when a restaurant limits its menu to things it does well.

The restaurant was clean and smelled of the ocean. Service was quick and friendly. Will definitely visit again
author: John P.

description:
We came here early one Saturday evening without reservations and were seated after about a 40-minute wait. The quality of their food was fairly inconsistent, with some items beging very good and some fairly subpar.

Good: - Juicy Scallop
- Oshizushi (fairly unique - haven't seen this anywhere else)

OK: - Chawanmushi w/ unagi (the egg custard was a little too liquid)
Hirasuzuki (not my favourite as it was not very flavourful)

Not Good: - S.T.A.S.H. (was a little too dry)
- Futomaki

The service was OK - they could definitely have been more attentive. Overall, Tsubasa is decent but there are better options for sushi in San Francisco.
author: Vikram N.

description: Came here for dinner, we had a spread of various rolls and nigiri (and lots of sake). Beautifully presented and several of the nigiri were garnished in such a way that you didn't need soy sauce/wasabi added. I have cheap taste in alcohol and stuck with my hot sake but everyone in our group seemed to enjoy the various cold sake options they got. The waitress was very attentive, friendly and helped with sake recs. Will definitely come back here.
author: Debra D.

description: Came here for the first time tonight. Everything is amazing!! Japanese uni is the best. Must try it. Our sushi chef John is amazing and recommend all the wonderful sashimi. I highly give this restaurant and our chef a 5 out of 5 star. If you are in SF. This is a must stop spot!
author: Jennifer C.

description: The food was delicious. I usually don't like sushi in SF I prefer LA sushi, but Tsubasa may have me rethink that evaluation.  The uni may have been the best thing there, but you can't go wrong with their omakase or their house special fish.  Also, they were very nice about the fact that we got rather drunk there on sake.
author: Diver G.

description:
I am not the type of girl to come to fancy restaurants and order expensive food and blow my money like it's nothing (I am frugal af and would rather find my way to dat dollar menu youfeelme). But, my boyfriend and I wanted to do something very special for our 2nd anniversary, he has more of the taste for the fancy, high class stuff so he thought we should give it a try. He's bae so of course I want him to be satisfied.

Make reservations! Not sure if they allow walk-ins but it's a very small, intimate restaurant with 3 or so servers. Dim lighting - big scoring points for bringing a special someone here or if you tryna impress your lady friend, cause I know for sure it made me some typa way (just my opinion lol). An older, more mature crowd here; as a young adult trying to adult, i felt like a real adult (my bank account says otherwise unfortunately qq). Small lulls of conversation everywhere around, it felt nice and soothing almost.

The servers were very tentative and so nice! Always coming by for refills and quickly clearing the table when I just about finish my plate.

We had ordered the 12-piece Nigiri Omakase ($68 per person) and I must say it's an experience. It will take time to get through Omakase (over an hour or so), but I think it's pleasant since you try little by little. By doing this, I don't feel bloated or too full when done and you get to interact in good conversation in between the courses. Definitely a must try and the vibe/service of Tsubasa made our 2nd anniversary that much more intimate and special.
author: Angelica M.

description: Being a self proclaimed Sushi enthusiast and have eaten at many high end sushi spots It's the best omakase deal in SF.  I've gone to tsubasa multiple times and chef peter never disappoints.  Will definitely be coming back!
author: Jane K.

description: Amazing sushi. Best I have had. Such a diverse selection and everything was just so fabulous.
author: J A.

description: Second time here was not a great experience. Nigiri was so-so, and service was extremely slow. High points were negitoro hand rolls, chutoro tataki, and chocolate barley frozen custard (minus the mochi). Our previous visit was at the sushi bar and much better overall. We might try again or give up forever.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
Went here a few weeks ago with some friends for the Omakase dinner. It was exquisite. The fish portions are generous and the selection was great. There were many types of fish that I never even had before, (all of which were tasty). Chef Peter knows his craft for sure. 

I usually don't like barracuda--too mushy, but that night he changed my mind. It wasn't "melted" according to him, which is a result of chefs buying less than par cuts. Will definitely be back.
author: Nam N.

description: Friendly sushi chef. Excellent food. Reminds me of Tokyo sushi places with small elegant atmosphere. Gets busy after 6pm. Get the Omakase 12 piece special $68:)
author: Piedad I.

description:
My boyfriend and I love Tsubasa.  We've been twice and the price point for the omakase and fish selection is amazing.  Sake prices could be a little better and we'd love to chat with the sushi chefs a bit more, but I appreciated that they recognized us on the second visit and get too busy to chat.

We'd love to go here every couple of weeks, but it can get pricey once you order an appetizer, omakase, and sake.  However, the level of sushi is comparable with much higher priced sushi restaurants in SF and make this place a hidden gem (and a steal!).  HIGHLY RECOMMEND.  Oh, and make reservations.
author: Karen W.

description: Tsubasa Sushi in San Francisco is an enjoyable fine dining restaurant for the average eater. Taste experts will be able to differentiate slight imperfections in the fish served. Their 8-piece omakase was priced at $50 even - expensive from an outsider's perspective but understandable and maybe even reasonable within the SF fine dining spectrum. Some notable pieces were the semi-raw sweet shrimp, which had a slight lemon dressing, and the summer flounder which was topped well. Both had perfect texture and tasted superb. The Canada salmon reminded me very much of smoked salmon with a hint of more "sushi salmon" flavor embedded. It was a refreshing touch to be eaten with rice. The uni, supposedly from Japan, was very mediocre - nothing special, and the aftertaste was not like other sea urchin I have eaten from Hokkaido (where most Japanese uni is received from in the United States). I was disappointed in their uni. On the contrary, the ikura (salmon eggs) was marinated very well and had no fishy aftertaste. The bluefin (maguro) chutoro was not cut well and showed Tsubasa's lackluster attention to detail when estimating taste from appearance. Tasted good, but not impressive. Service at this restauarant was excellent, although it took about 30 minutes to receive my second half of omakase (4 pieces) from the time I received the first half. Overall, Tsubasa is an atmosphere-based restaurant that delivers exquisite taste in some regard, yet misses perfection by a wide margin. 3.5/5
author: Ryan E.

description: Tsubasa Sushi is one of the best sushi restaurants I went in US. Its westernized decor is not like conventional Japanese sushi restaurants, but their dishes are authentic and the quality is even better than typical sushi restaurants in Japan in that price range ($50 per person) - I'm not comparing it with Jiro;) In fact, most of their fishes are imported fresh from Japan. We ordered zensai (appetizer) and a la carte nigiri sushi with cold sake. Sushi was served in a perfect order and timing. Su-meshi (=shari, rice) and seasoning are just right to enhance the taste of neta (topping). The chef (and waiter/waitress) definitely knows what they are supposed to do. If you want to eat just rolls or expect other Americanized Japanese dishes, go somewhere else. If you really want to try real nigiri suhi, go Tsubasa. Highly recommended!
author: Jun S.

description:
This place is the definition of average sushi. Nothing was beyond what you would expect at a random sushi place you might stumble into. Location wise yes, it's strategically placed in the heart of hayes valley so it seems like it's going to be great, but just expect standard. I've been here 4 times and the experience is the same each time. 

- Quality of fish is just okay, none of the rolls are unique or stand out
- If you like to order premium fish like Toro, it's not going to be as good as other places and I'd suggest to save your pennies for a better Toro experience (like O-toro a couple blocks away, a WAY WAY better spot)
- No gyoza or garlic, spicy edamame
- Miso soup is very watery and bland

Also, my ears were in shock when the waiter told us "sorry, the chef is not accepting nigiri orders right now unless you want to wait 30-40 minutes". It's simply unacceptable to tell a customer that at a sushi establishment. ESPECIALLY when it wasn't even that busy, 1/3 of the tables were empty on a Friday night. Sounds like they need to staff up with another chef.

If you're in the neighborhood and don't mind an average sushi experience, go for it. If you're expecting something to be reflective of 4.5 stars, don't go here and take your wallet to O-toro instead.
author: Pratul L.

description: came here for lunch today and thoroughly enjoyed it. it's a little expensive, especially or lunch, but the sushi was fresh, the miso soup was very good and the service was excellent. their are interesting choices of rolls and donburi. I don't understand why I haven't been here before, but I will be back for sure
author: Bob U.

description: Fish was fresh, ambiance was good but a little pricey for just "good" fish. Parking situation was reasonable on a week night late dinner, otherwise can be a difficult spot to drive to. Waitress was very attentive and explained everything clearly. Next time may try dining at the bar, if I ever get to return. Oh too many options, not enough calorie burning quotas.
author: Alice W.

description: This place was recommended by my friend.  Yes, this is a great place to have sushi.  I could not believe that the chef is Korean.  This place serve real Japanese food.  The server was great, too!  He speaks fluent Japanese and helped us a lot.  I will come back whenever I come back to San Francisco!
author: Kim O.

description:
Legit sushi
Great alcohol pairing
Great service 

Can't go wrong! 
The pressed sushi is the bomb
author: Austin L.

description: I've been here in the past and the food is good but the customer service is bad. I came here 30 minutes before closing time and they wouldn't sit us despite having empty tables.
author: Rafael C.

description: Fresh, quality, authentic sushi. Get the chef's daily selection! Great Service too. You won't be disappointed.
author: Mandana N.

description:
Disappointing...

Sat at the bar and watched a guy wrap sushi rolls with saran wrap all night. Based purely on yelp reviews I had expected a traditional Japanese restaurant but upon walking in soon discovered this was her another American - Japanese joint, not run by Japanese people. This places lacks quality and Japanese sophistication. 

Ordered some appetizers to start and the nigiri a la carte: 
Chawanmushi (crab)- lacked any flavor whatsoever 
Juicy scallop roll- scallop was sweet and silky but was masked by a blob of wasabi in the roll
